built with pdoc

exodus

exodus.py v 1.21.2 (seacas-py3) is a python wrapper of some of the exodus library (Python 3 Version)

Exodus is a common database for multiple application codes (mesh generators, analysis codes, visualization software, etc.) affording flexibility and robustness for both the application code developer and application code user. By using the Exodus data model, a user inherits the flexibility of using a large array of application codes (including vendor-supplied codes) which access this common data file directly or via translators.

The uses of the Exodus data model include the following:

  • problem definition -- mesh generation, specification of locations of boundary conditions and load application, specification of material types.

  • simulation -- model input and results output.

  • visualization -- model verification, results postprocessing, data interrogation, and analysis tracking.

The data in Exodus files can be divided into three primary categories: initialization data, model data, and results data.

  • Initialization data includes sizing parameters (number of nodes, number of elements, etc.), optional quality assurance information (names of codes that have operated on the data), and optional informational text.

  • The model is described by data which are static (do not change through time). This data includes nodal coordinates, element connectivity (node lists for each element), element attributes, and node sets and side sets (used to aid in applying loading conditions and boundary constraints).

  • The results are optional and include five types of variables -- nodal, element, nodeset, sideset, and global -- each of which is stored through time. Nodal results are output (at each time step) for all the nodes in the model. An example of a nodal variable is displacement in the X direction. Element, nodeset, and sideset results are output (at each time step) for all entities (elements, nodes, sides) in one or more entity block. For example, stress may be an element variable. Another use of element variables is to record element status (a binary flag indicating whether each element is "alive" or "dead") through time. Global results are output (at each time step) for a single element or node, or for a single property. Linear momentum of a structure and the acceleration at a particular point are both examples of global variables. Although these examples correspond to typical FE applications, the data format is flexible enough to accommodate a spectrum of uses.

Copyright(C) 1999-2023 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC (NTESS). Under the terms of Contract DE-NA0003525 with NTESS, the U.S. Government retains certain rights in this software.

See packages/seacas/LICENSE for details

   1"""
   2exodus.py v 1.21.2 (seacas-py3) is a python wrapper of some of the exodus library
   3(Python 3 Version)
   4
   5Exodus is a common database for multiple application codes (mesh
   6generators, analysis codes, visualization software, etc.) affording
   7flexibility and robustness for both
   8the application code developer and application code user. By using the
   9Exodus data model, a user inherits the flexibility of using a large
  10array of application codes (including vendor-supplied codes) which
  11access this common data file directly or via translators.
  12
  13The uses of the Exodus data model include the following:
  14
  15* problem definition -- mesh generation, specification
  16  of locations of boundary conditions and load application, specification
  17  of material types.
  18
  19* simulation -- model input and results output.
  20
  21* visualization -- model verification, results postprocessing,
  22  data interrogation, and analysis tracking.
  23
  24The data in Exodus files can be divided into three primary categories:
  25initialization data, model data, and results data.
  26
  27* Initialization data includes sizing parameters (number of
  28nodes, number of elements, etc.), optional quality assurance
  29information (names of codes that have operated on the data),
  30and optional informational text.
  31
  32* The model is described by data which are static (do not change
  33through time). This data includes nodal coordinates, element
  34connectivity (node lists for each element), element attributes,
  35and node sets and side sets (used to aid in applying loading
  36conditions and boundary constraints).
  37
  38* The results are optional and include five types of variables -- nodal,
  39element, nodeset, sideset, and global -- each of which is stored
  40through time. Nodal results are output (at each time step) for all the
  41nodes in the model. An example of a nodal variable is displacement in
  42the X direction. Element, nodeset, and sideset results are output (at
  43each time step) for all entities (elements, nodes, sides) in one or
  44more entity block. For example, stress may be an element
  45variable. Another use of element variables is to record element status
  46(a binary flag indicating whether each element is "alive" or "dead")
  47through time. Global results are output (at each time step) for a
  48single element or node, or for a single property. Linear momentum of a
  49structure and the acceleration at a particular point are both examples
  50of global variables. Although these examples correspond to typical FE
  51applications, the data format is flexible enough to accommodate a
  52spectrum of uses.
  53
  54Copyright(C) 1999-2023 National Technology & Engineering Solutions
  55of Sandia, LLC (NTESS).  Under the terms of Contract DE-NA0003525 with
  56NTESS, the U.S. Government retains certain rights in this software.
  57
  58See packages/seacas/LICENSE for details
  59
  60"""
  61
  62import sys
  63if sys.version_info[0] < 3:
  64    raise Exception("Python-3 version. If using python-2, try `import exodus2 as exodus`")
  65
  66import ctypes
  67import os
  68import locale
  69from enum import Enum
  70
  71EXODUS_PY_COPYRIGHT_AND_LICENSE = __doc__
  72
  73EXODUS_PY_VERSION = "1.21.2 (seacas-py3)"
  74
  75EXODUS_PY_COPYRIGHT = """
  76You are using exodus.py v 1.21.2 (seacas-py3), a python wrapper of some of the exodus library.
  77
  78Copyright (c) 2013-2023 National Technology &
  79Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC (NTESS).  Under the terms of
  80Contract DE-NA0003525 with NTESS, the U.S. Government retains certain
  81rights in this software.
  82"""
  83
  84EXODUS_PY_CONTACTS = """
  85Authors:
  86  Greg Sjaardema   (gdsjaar@sandia.gov)
  87  Mario LoPrinzi   (mvlopri@sandia.gov)
  88  Timothy Shelton  (trshelt@sandia.gov)
  89  Michael Veilleux (mgveill@sandia.gov)
  90  David Littlewood (djlittl@sandia.gov)
  91"""
  92
  93# show the banner on first use
  94SHOW_BANNER = True
  95
  96# Documentation is generated on a Mac laptop using:
  97# pdoc --force --html ../lib/exodus.py
  98
  99sys.dont_write_bytecode = True
 100
 101ONELINE = "Gather from or export to Exodus files using the Exodus library"
 102
 103
 104def basename(file_name):
 105    """
 106    Extract base name from file_name.
 107    `basename("test.e") -> "test"`
 108    """
 109    return os.path.splitext(file_name)[0]
 110
 111
 112def getExodusVersion():
 113    """
 114    Parse the exodusII.h header file and return the version number or 0 if not
 115    found.
 116    """
 117
 118    return _parse_exodus_version('#define EXODUS_VERSION       "8.22"')
 119
 120
 121def _parse_exodus_version(version_string):
 122    if version_string:
 123        assert version_string.startswith("#define EXODUS_VERSION "), "Received a incorrectly formated verstion string. Please check the CMakeLists.txt"
 124        return int(version_string.strip().split()[-1].strip('"').replace('.', ''))
 125    else:
 126        return 0
 127
 128
 129try:
 130    locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, 'en_US.utf-8')
 131except locale.Error:
 132    locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, 'C')
 133
 134
 135class ex_options(Enum):
 136    """
 137    `ex_opts()` function codes - codes are OR'ed into exopts
 138
 139    Parameters
 140    ----------
 141    EX_DEFAULT
 142         Application responsible for calling `ex_err()` to get error and warning messages to output; library is quiet
 143    EX_VERBOSE
 144         Verbose mode -- output all error and warning messages
 145    EX_DEBUG
 146         Output Debug messages
 147    EX_ABORT
 148         If an error is detected, library will abort instead of letting application decide
 149    EX_NULLVERBOSE
 150         Output error and warning messages for NULL Entity errors and warnings
 151    """
 152    EX_DEFAULT = 0
 153    EX_VERBOSE = 1
 154    EX_DEBUG = 2
 155    EX_ABORT = 4
 156    EX_NULLVERBOSE = 8
 157
 158
 159ACCESS = os.getenv('ACCESS', '/Users/gdsjaar/src/seacas')
 160if os.uname()[0] == 'Darwin':
 161    EXODUS_SO = f"{ACCESS}/lib/libexodus.dylib"
 162else:
 163    EXODUS_SO = f"{ACCESS}/lib/libexodus.so"
 164pip_path = os.path.dirname(__file__)
 165pip_so_path = os.path.join(pip_path, "libexodus.so")
 166try:
 167    EXODUS_LIB = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary(pip_so_path)
 168except Exception:
 169    EXODUS_LIB = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary(EXODUS_SO)
 170
 171MAX_STR_LENGTH = 32      # match exodus default
 172MAX_NAME_LENGTH = 256     # match exodus default
 173MAX_LINE_LENGTH = 80      # match exodus default
 174
 175EX_API_VERSION_NODOT = getExodusVersion()
 176EX_READ = 0x0002 if EX_API_VERSION_NODOT >= 608 else 0x0000
 177EX_WRITE = 0x0001  # ex_open(): open existing file for appending.
 178EX_NOCLOBBER = 0x0004  # does not overwrite existing exodus file
 179EX_CLOBBER = 0x0008  # overwrites existing exodus file
 180
 181EX_NORMAL_MODEL = 0x0010  # disable mods that permit storage of larger models
 182EX_64BIT_OFFSET = 0x0020  # enable mods that permit storage of larger models
 183# enable mods that permit storage of larger models
 184EX_LARGE_MODEL = EX_64BIT_OFFSET
 185EX_64BIT_DATA = 0x400000  # CDF-5 format: classic model but 64 bit dimensions and sizes
 186EX_NETCDF4 = 0x0040  # use the hdf5-based netcdf4 output
 187EX_NOSHARE = 0x0080  # Do not open netcdf file in "share" mode
 188EX_SHARE = 0x0100  # Do open netcdf file in "share" mode
 189EX_NOCLASSIC = 0x0200  # Do not force netcdf to classic mode in netcdf4 mode
 190
 191EX_DISKLESS = 0x100000  # Experimental
 192EX_MMAP = 0x200000  # Experimental
 193
 194# Need to distinguish between storage on database (DB in name) and
 195# passed through the API functions (API in name).
 196EX_MAPS_INT64_DB = 0x0400  # All maps (id, order, ...) store int64_t values
 197# All entity ids (sets, blocks, maps) are int64_t values
 198EX_IDS_INT64_DB = 0x0800
 199# All integer bulk data (local indices, counts, maps); not ids
 200EX_BULK_INT64_DB = 0x1000
 201# All of the above...
 202EX_ALL_INT64_DB = EX_MAPS_INT64_DB + EX_IDS_INT64_DB + EX_BULK_INT64_DB
 203
 204EX_MAPS_INT64_API = 0x2000  # All maps (id, order, ...) store int64_t values
 205# All entity ids (sets, blocks, maps) are int64_t values
 206EX_IDS_INT64_API = 0x4000
 207# All integer bulk data (local indices, counts, maps); not ids
 208EX_BULK_INT64_API = 0x8000
 209EX_INQ_INT64_API = 0x10000  # Integers passed to/from ex_inquire are int64_t
 210# All of the above...
 211EX_ALL_INT64_API = EX_MAPS_INT64_API + EX_IDS_INT64_API + \
 212    EX_BULK_INT64_API + EX_INQ_INT64_API
 213
 214# Parallel IO mode flags...
 215EX_MPIIO = 0x20000
 216EX_MPIPOSIX = 0x40000  # \deprecated As of libhdf5 1.8.13.
 217EX_PNETCDF = 0x80000
 218
 219# set exodus error output option
 220exErrPrintMode = ctypes.c_int(ex_options.EX_VERBOSE.value)
 221EXODUS_LIB.ex_opts(exErrPrintMode)
 222
 223
 224class ex_inquiry(Enum):
 225    EX_INQ_FILE_TYPE = 1                    # inquire EXODUS file type
 226    EX_INQ_API_VERS = 2                     # inquire API version number
 227    EX_INQ_DB_VERS = 3                      # inquire database version number
 228    EX_INQ_TITLE = 4                        # inquire database title
 229    EX_INQ_DIM = 5                          # inquire number of dimensions
 230    EX_INQ_NODES = 6                        # inquire number of nodes
 231    EX_INQ_ELEM = 7                         # inquire number of elements
 232    EX_INQ_ELEM_BLK = 8                     # inquire number of element blocks
 233    EX_INQ_NODE_SETS = 9                    # inquire number of node sets
 234    EX_INQ_NS_NODE_LEN = 10                 # inquire length of node set node list
 235    EX_INQ_SIDE_SETS = 11                   # inquire number of side sets
 236    EX_INQ_SS_NODE_LEN = 12                 # inquire length of side set node list
 237    EX_INQ_SS_ELEM_LEN = 13                 # inquire length of side set element list
 238    EX_INQ_QA = 14                          # inquire number of QA records
 239    EX_INQ_INFO = 15                        # inquire number of info records
 240    EX_INQ_TIME = 16                        # inquire number of time steps in the database
 241    EX_INQ_EB_PROP = 17                     # inquire number of element block properties
 242    EX_INQ_NS_PROP = 18                     # inquire number of node set properties
 243    EX_INQ_SS_PROP = 19                     # inquire number of side set properties
 244    # inquire length of node set distribution factor list
 245    EX_INQ_NS_DF_LEN = 20
 246    # inquire length of side set distribution factor list
 247    EX_INQ_SS_DF_LEN = 21
 248    EX_INQ_LIB_VERS = 22                    # inquire API Lib vers number
 249    EX_INQ_EM_PROP = 23                     # inquire number of element map properties
 250    EX_INQ_NM_PROP = 24                     # inquire number of node map properties
 251    EX_INQ_ELEM_MAP = 25                    # inquire number of element maps
 252    EX_INQ_NODE_MAP = 26                    # inquire number of node maps
 253    EX_INQ_EDGE = 27                        # inquire number of edges
 254    EX_INQ_EDGE_BLK = 28                    # inquire number of edge blocks
 255    EX_INQ_EDGE_SETS = 29                   # inquire number of edge sets
 256    # inquire length of concat edge set edge list
 257    EX_INQ_ES_LEN = 30
 258    # inquire length of concat edge set dist factor list
 259    EX_INQ_ES_DF_LEN = 31
 260    # inquire number of properties stored per edge block
 261    EX_INQ_EDGE_PROP = 32
 262    # inquire number of properties stored per edge set
 263    EX_INQ_ES_PROP = 33
 264    EX_INQ_FACE = 34                        # inquire number of faces
 265    EX_INQ_FACE_BLK = 35                    # inquire number of face blocks
 266    EX_INQ_FACE_SETS = 36                   # inquire number of face sets
 267    # inquire length of concat face set face list
 268    EX_INQ_FS_LEN = 37
 269    # inquire length of concat face set dist factor list
 270    EX_INQ_FS_DF_LEN = 38
 271    # inquire number of properties stored per face block
 272    EX_INQ_FACE_PROP = 39
 273    # inquire number of properties stored per face set
 274    EX_INQ_FS_PROP = 40
 275    EX_INQ_ELEM_SETS = 41                   # inquire number of element sets
 276    # inquire length of concat element set element list
 277    EX_INQ_ELS_LEN = 42
 278    # inquire length of concat element set dist factor list
 279    EX_INQ_ELS_DF_LEN = 43
 280    # inquire number of properties stored per elem set
 281    EX_INQ_ELS_PROP = 44
 282    EX_INQ_EDGE_MAP = 45                    # inquire number of edge maps
 283    EX_INQ_FACE_MAP = 46                    # inquire number of face maps
 284    EX_INQ_COORD_FRAMES = 47                # inquire number of coordinate frames
 285    # inquire size of MAX_NAME_LENGTH dimension on database
 286    EX_INQ_DB_MAX_ALLOWED_NAME_LENGTH = 48
 287    # inquire size of MAX_NAME_LENGTH dimension on database
 288    EX_INQ_DB_MAX_USED_NAME_LENGTH = 49
 289    # inquire client-specified max size of returned names
 290    EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH = 50
 291    # inquire size of floating-point values stored on database
 292    EX_INQ_DB_FLOAT_SIZE = 51
 293    EX_INQ_ASSEMBLY = 60
 294    EX_INQ_BLOB = 61
 295    EX_INQ_INVALID = -1
 296
 297
 298class ex_type(Enum):
 299    EX_CHAR = 2     # NC_CHAR (from netcdf.h)
 300    EX_INTEGER = 4  # NC_INT (from netcdf.h)
 301    EX_DOUBLE = 6   # NC_DOUBLE (from netcdf.h)
 302    EX_INVALID = -1
 303
 304
 305def ex_type_map(type):
 306    """
 307    Map the exodus inquiry flags to an enum value.
 308    """
 309    return ex_type[type].value
 310
 311
 312def ex_inquiry_map(inquiry):
 313    """
 314    Map the exodus inquiry flags to an enum value.
 315    """
 316    return ex_inquiry[inquiry].value
 317
 318
 319def ex_obj_to_inq(objType):
 320    """
 321    Return the ex_inquiry string corresponding to the specified objType.
 322    This can be passed to the ex_inquiry_map() function to get the number of
 323    objects of the specified objType
 324    """
 325    entity_dictionary = {
 326        'EX_ASSEMBLY': 'EX_INQ_ASSEMBLY',
 327        'EX_BLOB': 'EX_INQ_BLOB',
 328        'EX_EDGE_BLOCK': 'EX_INQ_EDGE_BLK',
 329        'EX_FACE_BLOCK': 'EX_INQ_FACE_BLK',
 330        'EX_ELEM_BLOCK': 'EX_INQ_ELEM_BLK',
 331        'EX_NODE_SET': 'EX_INQ_NODE_SETS',
 332        'EX_EDGE_SET': 'EX_INQ_EDGE_SETS',
 333        'EX_FACE_SET': 'EX_INQ_FACE_SETS',
 334        'EX_ELEM_SET': 'EX_INQ_ELEM_SETS',
 335        'EX_SIDE_SET': 'EX_INQ_SIDE_SETS',
 336        'EX_NODE_MAP': 'EX_INQ_NODES',
 337        'EX_EDGE_MAP': 'EX_INQ_EDGE',
 338        'EX_FACE_MAP': 'EX_INQ_FACE',
 339        'EX_ELEM_MAP': 'EX_INQ_ELEM',
 340    }
 341
 342    return entity_dictionary.get(objType, -1)
 343
 344
 345def ex_entity_type_to_objType(entity_type):
 346    """
 347    """
 348    entity_dictionary = {
 349        get_entity_type('EX_ASSEMBLY'): "assembly",
 350        get_entity_type('EX_BLOB'): "blob",
 351        get_entity_type('EX_EDGE_BLOCK'): "edge block",
 352        get_entity_type('EX_FACE_BLOCK'): "face block",
 353        get_entity_type('EX_ELEM_BLOCK'): "element block",
 354        get_entity_type('EX_NODE_SET'): "node set",
 355        get_entity_type('EX_EDGE_SET'): "edge set",
 356        get_entity_type('EX_FACE_SET'): "face set",
 357        get_entity_type('EX_ELEM_SET'): "element set",
 358        get_entity_type('EX_SIDE_SET'): "side set",
 359        get_entity_type('EX_NODE_MAP'): "node map",
 360        get_entity_type('EX_EDGE_MAP'): "edge map",
 361        get_entity_type('EX_FACE_MAP'): "face map",
 362        get_entity_type('EX_ELEM_MAP'): "element map"
 363    }
 364
 365    return entity_dictionary.get(entity_type, 'EX_INVALID')
 366
 367
 368class ex_entity_type(Enum):
 369    """
 370    The ex_entity_type enum from the exodusII.h include file
 371
 372    Parameters
 373    ----------
 374    EX_NODAL
 375         nodal \"block\" for variables
 376    EX_NODE_BLOCK
 377         alias for EX_NODAL
 378    EX_NODE_SET
 379         node set property code
 380    EX_EDGE_BLOCK
 381         edge block property code
 382    EX_EDGE_SET
 383         edge set property code
 384    EX_FACE_BLOCK
 385         face block property code
 386    EX_FACE_SET
 387         face set property code
 388    EX_ELEM_BLOCK
 389         element block property code
 390    EX_ELEM_SET
 391         face set property code
 392    EX_SIDE_SET
 393         side set property code
 394    EX_ELEM_MAP
 395         element map property code
 396    EX_NODE_MAP
 397         node map property code
 398    EX_EDGE_MAP
 399         edge map property code
 400    EX_FACE_MAP
 401         face map property code
 402    EX_GLOBAL
 403         global \"block\" for variables
 404    EX_COORDINATE
 405         kluge so some internal wrapper functions work
 406    EX_ASSEMBLY
 407         assemblies (collections of other entities)
 408    EX_BLOB
 409         blob (arbitrary sized binary object)
 410    EX_INVALID
 411         invalid
 412    """
 413    EX_NODAL = 14
 414    EX_NODE_BLOCK = 14
 415    EX_NODE_SET = 2
 416    EX_EDGE_BLOCK = 6
 417    EX_EDGE_SET = 7
 418    EX_FACE_BLOCK = 8
 419    EX_FACE_SET = 9
 420    EX_ELEM_BLOCK = 1
 421    EX_ELEM_SET = 10
 422    EX_SIDE_SET = 3
 423    EX_ELEM_MAP = 4
 424    EX_NODE_MAP = 5
 425    EX_EDGE_MAP = 11
 426    EX_FACE_MAP = 12
 427    EX_GLOBAL = 13
 428    EX_COORDINATE = 15
 429    EX_ASSEMBLY = 16
 430    EX_BLOB = 17
 431    EX_INVALID = -1
 432
 433
 434def get_entity_type(varType):
 435    """
 436    Map the exodus ex_entity_type flags to an integer value.
 437    """
 438    try:
 439        return ex_entity_type[varType].value
 440    except KeyError:
 441        return varType if (isinstance(varType, int)) else varType.value
 442
 443
 444# init params struct
 445class ex_init_params(ctypes.Structure):
 446    """
 447    Parameters defining the model dimension, note that many are optional.
 448
 449    Parameters
 450    ----------
 451    num_dim : int
 452        number of model dimensions
 453    num_nodes : int
 454        number of model nodes
 455    num_edge : int
 456        number of model edges
 457    num_edge_blk : int
 458        number of model edge blocks
 459    num_face : int
 460        number of model faces
 461    num_face_blk : int
 462        number of model face blocks
 463    num_elem : int
 464        number of model elements
 465    num_elem_blk : int
 466        number of model element blocks
 467    num_node_sets : int
 468        number of model node sets
 469    num_edge_sets : int
 470        number of model edge sets
 471    num_face_sets : int
 472        number of model face sets
 473    num_side_sets : int
 474        number of model side sets
 475    num_elem_sets : int
 476        number of model elem sets
 477    num_node_maps : int
 478        number of model node maps
 479    num_edge_maps : int
 480        number of model edge maps
 481    num_face_maps : int
 482        number of model face maps
 483    num_elem_maps : int
 484        number of model elem maps
 485    num_assembly : int
 486        number of assemblies
 487    num_blob : int
 488        number of blobs
 489    """
 490    _fields_ = [("title", ctypes.c_char * (MAX_LINE_LENGTH + 1)),
 491                ("num_dim", ctypes.c_longlong),
 492                ("num_nodes", ctypes.c_longlong),
 493                ("num_edge", ctypes.c_longlong),
 494                ("num_edge_blk", ctypes.c_longlong),
 495                ("num_face", ctypes.c_longlong),
 496                ("num_face_blk", ctypes.c_longlong),
 497                ("num_elem", ctypes.c_longlong),
 498                ("num_elem_blk", ctypes.c_longlong),
 499                ("num_node_sets", ctypes.c_longlong),
 500                ("num_edge_sets", ctypes.c_longlong),
 501                ("num_face_sets", ctypes.c_longlong),
 502                ("num_side_sets", ctypes.c_longlong),
 503                ("num_elem_sets", ctypes.c_longlong),
 504                ("num_node_maps", ctypes.c_longlong),
 505                ("num_edge_maps", ctypes.c_longlong),
 506                ("num_face_maps", ctypes.c_longlong),
 507                ("num_elem_maps", ctypes.c_longlong),
 508                ("num_assembly", ctypes.c_longlong),
 509                ("num_blob", ctypes.c_longlong)]
 510
 511
 512class assembly:
 513    def __init__(self, name, id, type):
 514        self.name = name
 515        self.id = id
 516        if isinstance(type, str):
 517            type = ex_entity_type[type].value
 518        if isinstance(type, ex_entity_type):
 519            type = type.value
 520        self.type = type
 521        self.entity_list = []
 522
 523    def __repr__(self):
 524        return "assembly(name=%r, type=%r, id=%r, members=%r)" % (self.name, self.type, self.id, self.entity_list)
 525
 526
 527class ex_assembly(ctypes.Structure):
 528    """
 529    Structure defining the assembly parameters.
 530
 531    Parameters
 532    ----------
 533    id : int64_t
 534    name : char *
 535    type : ex_entity_type
 536    entity_count : int
 537    entity_list : void_int *
 538    """
 539    _fields_ = [("id", ctypes.c_longlong),
 540                ("name", ctypes.c_char_p),
 541                ("type", ctypes.c_int),
 542                ("entity_count", ctypes.c_int),
 543                ("entity_list", ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_longlong))]
 544
 545
 546def setup_ex_assembly(assembly):
 547    ctype_assem = ex_assembly(id=assembly.id, name=assembly.name.encode(), type=assembly.type)
 548    ctype_assem.entity_count = len(assembly.entity_list)
 549    ctype_assem.entity_list = (ctypes.c_longlong * ctype_assem.entity_count)(*assembly.entity_list)
 550    return ctype_assem
 551
 552
 553class blob(object):
 554    def __init__(self, name, id, num_entry):
 555        self.name = name
 556        self.id = id
 557        self.num_entry = num_entry
 558
 559    def __repr__(self):
 560        return "blob(name=%r, id=%r, num_entry=%r)" % (self.name, self.id, self.num_entry)
 561
 562
 563class ex_blob(ctypes.Structure):
 564    """
 565    Structure defining the blob parameters.
 566
 567    Parameters
 568    ----------
 569    id : int64_t
 570    name : char *
 571    num_entry : int64_t
 572    """
 573    _fields_ = [("id", ctypes.c_longlong),
 574                ("name", ctypes.c_char_p),
 575                ("num_entry", ctypes.c_longlong)]
 576
 577
 578class attribute:
 579    def __init__(self, name, type, id):
 580        self.name = name
 581        if isinstance(type, str):
 582            type = ex_entity_type[type].value
 583        if isinstance(type, ex_entity_type):
 584            type = type.value
 585        self.entity_type = type
 586        self.entity_id = id
 587        self.values = []
 588
 589    def __repr__(self):
 590        return "attribute(name=%r, entity_type=%r, entity_id=%r, values=%r)" % (self.name, self.entity_type, self.entity_id, self.values)
 591
 592
 593class ex_attribute(ctypes.Structure):
 594    """
 595    Used for accessing underlying exodus library...
 596
 597    Parameters
 598    ----------
 599    entity_type : ex_entity_type
 600    entity_id : int64_t
 601    name : char[257]
 602    type : ex_type
 603    value_count : int
 604    values : void*
 605    """
 606    _fields_ = [("entity_type", ctypes.c_int),
 607                ("entity_id", ctypes.c_longlong),
 608                ("name", ctypes.c_char * 257),
 609                ("type", ctypes.c_int),
 610                ("value_count", ctypes.c_int),
 611                ("values", ctypes.c_void_p)]
 612
 613
 614class exodus:
 615    """
 616    The exodus model abstraction
 617    """
 618
 619    #
 620    # construction of a new exodus object
 621    #
 622    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
 623
 624    def __init__(self, file, mode=None, array_type='ctype', title=None,
 625                 numDims=None, numNodes=None, numElems=None, numBlocks=None,
 626                 numNodeSets=None, numSideSets=None, numAssembly=None,
 627                 numBlob=None, init_params=None, io_size=0):
 628        """
 629        Open exodus database for data insertion/extraction.
 630
 631        Parameters
 632        ----------
 633        file_name : string
 634           name of exodus file to open
 635        mode : string
 636          'r' for read, 'a' for append, 'w' for write, 'w+' for write+clobber existing file
 637        title : string
 638           database title
 639        array_type : string
 640           'ctype' for c-type arrays, 'numpy' for numpy arrays
 641        num_dims : int
 642           number of model dimensions ('w'/'w+' mode only)
 643        num_nodes : int
 644           number of model nodes ('w'/'w+' mode only)
 645        num_elems : int
 646           number of model elements ('w'/'w+' mode only)
 647        num_blocks : int
 648           number of model element blocks ('w'/'w+' mode only)
 649        num_ns : int
 650           number of model node sets ('w'/'w+' mode only)
 651        num_ss : int
 652           number of model side sets ('w'/'w+' mode only)
 653
 654        init_params : ex_init_params
 655           see `exodus.ex_init_params` for more info.
 656
 657        Returns
 658        -------
 659        exo : exodus object
 660            the open exodus database
 661
 662        Usage
 663        -----
 664
 665        >>> ex_pars = ex_init_params(num_dim=numDims, num_nodes=numNodes,
 666        ...                          num_elem=numElems, num_elem_blk=numElemBlocks, num_assembly=numAssembly)
 667
 668        >>> exo = exodus(file_name, mode=mode, title=title,
 669        ...             array_type=array_type, init_params=ex_pars)
 670        >>> with exodus(file_name, mode=mode, title=title,\
 671        ...             array_type=array_type, init_params=ex_pars) as exo:
 672        ...     pass
 673        """
 674        global SHOW_BANNER
 675        if SHOW_BANNER:
 676            print(EXODUS_PY_COPYRIGHT)
 677            SHOW_BANNER = False
 678
 679        if mode is None:
 680            mode = 'r'
 681
 682        if array_type == 'numpy':
 683            # Import numpy to convert from c-type arrays to numpy arrays
 684            # (Numpy is imported here rather than at the module level, so that
 685            # the import only occurs if the user specifies a numpy array type.
 686            # This way, platforms without numpy installed can still import the
 687            # exodus.py module and just use ctype arrays.)
 688            import numpy as np
 689            self.np = np
 690            self.use_numpy = True
 691            # Warnings module is needed to suppress the invalid warning when
 692            # converting from c-type arrays to numpy arrays
 693            # http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4964101/pep-3118-warning-when-using-ctypes-array-as-numpy-array
 694            import warnings
 695            self.warnings = warnings
 696        else:
 697            self.use_numpy = False
 698
 699        self.EXODUS_LIB = EXODUS_LIB
 700        self.fileName = str(file)
 701        self.basename = basename(file)
 702        self.modeChar = mode
 703        self.fileId = None
 704        self.__open(io_size=io_size)
 705        EXODUS_LIB.ex_set_max_name_length(self.fileId, MAX_NAME_LENGTH)
 706        if mode.lower() in ['w', 'w+']:
 707            if init_params is not None:
 708                self.init_params = init_params
 709                if title is not None:
 710                    self.init_params.title = title
 711                self.put_info_ext(self.init_params)
 712            else:
 713                if numNodeSets is None:
 714                    numNodeSets = 0
 715                if numSideSets is None:
 716                    numSideSets = 0
 717                if numNodes is None:
 718                    numNodes = 0
 719                if numElems is None:
 720                    numElems = 0
 721                if numBlocks is None:
 722                    numBlocks = 0
 723
 724                info = [title, numDims, numNodes, numElems, numBlocks,
 725                        numNodeSets, numSideSets]
 726                if None not in info:
 727                    self.__ex_put_info(info)
 728
 729            self.numTimes = ctypes.c_int(0)
 730        else:
 731            self.__ex_get_info()
 732            self.numTimes = ctypes.c_int(
 733                self.__ex_inquire_int(
 734                    ex_inquiry_map('EX_INQ_TIME')))
 735
 736        self.coordsX = None
 737        self.coordsY = None
 738        self.coordsZ = None
 739        self.times = None
 740
 741    def __enter__(self):
 742        return self
 743
 744    def __exit__(self, type, value, traceback):
 745        self.close()
 746        if not traceback:
 747            return True
 748
 749    def summarize(self):
 750        """
 751        Outputs a summary of the exodus file data. Output is similar to:
 752        ```
 753        Database: base_ioshell_copy.e
 754        Title:  This is the title
 755
 756        Number of spatial dimensions = 3                                                 Number of global variables     = 10
 757        Number of node blocks        = 1         Number of nodes              = 1,331    Number of nodal variables      =  2
 758        Number of element blocks     = 1         Number of elements           = 1,000    Number of element variables    =  5
 759        Number of node sets          = 3         Length of node list          =   363    Number of nodeset variables    =  4
 760        Number of element side sets  = 3         Length of element sides      =   300    Number of sideset variables    =  3
 761        Number of assemblies         = 4                                                 Number of assembly variables   = 10
 762        Number of blobs              = 0                                                 Number of blob     variables   =  0
 763        Number of time steps         = 5
 764        ```
 765        """
 766
 767        sidesets = self.get_ids('EX_SIDE_SET')
 768        total_sides = sum(self.num_faces_in_side_set(sideset) for sideset in sidesets)
 769        nodesets = self.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')
 770        total_ns_nodes = sum(self.num_nodes_in_node_set(nodeset) for nodeset in nodesets)
 771
 772        num_glo_vars = self.get_variable_number('EX_GLOBAL')
 773        num_nod_vars = self.get_variable_number('EX_NODAL')
 774        num_ele_vars = self.get_variable_number('EX_ELEM_BLOCK')
 775        num_ns_vars = self.get_variable_number('EX_NODE_SET')
 776        num_ss_vars = self.get_variable_number('EX_SIDE_SET')
 777        num_assem_vars = self.get_reduction_variable_number('EX_ASSEMBLY')
 778        num_blob_vars = self.get_reduction_variable_number('EX_BLOB')
 779
 780        print("\n Database: {0}\n"
 781              " Title:\t{17}\n\n"
 782              " Number of spatial dimensions = {1:3d}\t"
 783              "                                   {2:11s}\t"
 784              " Number of global variables     = {11:6d}\n"
 785              " Number of node blocks        = {5:3d}\t"
 786              " Number of nodes              = {3:10n}\t"
 787              " Number of nodal variables      = {12:6d}\n"
 788              " Number of element blocks     = {6:3n}\t"
 789              " Number of elements           = {4:10n}\t"
 790              " Number of element variables    = {13:6d}\n"
 791              " Number of node sets          = {7:3n}\t"
 792              " Length of node list          = {9:10n}\t"
 793              " Number of nodeset variables    = {14:6d}\n"
 794              " Number of element side sets  = {8:3n}\t"
 795              " Length of element sides      = {10:10n}\t"
 796              " Number of sideset variables    = {15:6d}\n"
 797              " Number of assemblies         = {18:3n}\t"
 798              "                                   {2:11s}\t"
 799              " Number of assembly red vars    = {19:6d}\n"
 800              " Number of blobs              = {20:3n}\t"
 801              "                                   {2:11s}\t"
 802              " Number of blob red vars        = {21:6d}\n"
 803              " Number of time steps         = {16:3n}\n"
 804              .format(self.fileName,
 805                      self.num_dimensions(), "",
 806                      self.num_nodes(),
 807                      self.num_elems(),
 808                      1,
 809                      self.num_blks(),
 810                      self.num_node_sets(),
 811                      self.num_side_sets(),
 812                      total_ns_nodes, total_sides,
 813                      num_glo_vars, num_nod_vars, num_ele_vars,
 814                      num_ns_vars, num_ss_vars, self.num_times(), self.title(),
 815                      self.num_assembly(), num_assem_vars,
 816                      self.num_blob(), num_blob_vars))
 817
 818    def put_info_ext(self, p):
 819        """
 820        put initialization information into exodus file
 821
 822        >>> e.put_info_ext(info_struct)
 823        """
 824        if len(p.title) > MAX_LINE_LENGTH:
 825            print(f'WARNING: Exodus title \"{p.title}\" exceeds maximum line length ({MAX_LINE_LENGTH}). It will be truncated.')
 826
 827            p.title = p.title[-1 * MAX_LINE_LENGTH:]
 828
 829        self.Title = ctypes.create_string_buffer(p.title, MAX_LINE_LENGTH + 1)
 830        self.numDim = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_dim)
 831        self.numNodes = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_nodes)
 832        self.numElem = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_elem)
 833        self.numElemBlk = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_elem_blk)
 834        self.numNodeSets = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_node_sets)
 835        self.numSideSets = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_side_sets)
 836        self.numAssembly = ctypes.c_longlong(p.num_assembly)
 837
 838        EXODUS_LIB.ex_put_init_ext(self.fileId, ctypes.byref(p))
 839        return True
 840
 841    def copy(self, fileName, include_transient=False, mode='a'):
 842        """
 843        Copies exodus database to file_name and returns an opened copy as a
 844        new exodus object. This object will need to be closed when it is done
 845        being used.
 846
 847        >>> exo_copy = exo.copy(file_name)
 848        >>> exo_copy.close()
 849
 850        Parameters
 851        ----------
 852        file_name : str
 853            name of exodus file to open
 854
 855        Returns
 856        -------
 857        exo_copy : exodus object opened in append mode by default
 858        """
 859        i64Status = EXODUS_LIB.ex_int64_status(self.fileId)
 860        fileId = EXODUS_LIB.ex_create_int(fileName.encode('ascii'), EX_NOCLOBBER | i64Status,
 861                                          ctypes.byref(self.comp_ws),
 862                                          ctypes.byref(self.io_ws),
 863                                          EX_API_VERSION_NODOT)
 864
 865        self.copy_file(fileId, include_transient)
 866        EXODUS_LIB.ex_close(fileId)
 867
 868        return exodus(fileName, mode)
 869
 870    def copy_file(self, file_id, include_transient=False):
 871        """
 872        Copies exodus database to the database pointed to by `fileId`
 873        Returns the passed in `file_id`.
 874
 875        >>> with exodus.exodus(file_name, mode='w') as exofile:
 876        >>>     with exo.copy_file(exofile.fileId, include_transient=True) as exo_copy:
 877        >>>         exo_copy.close()
 878
 879        Parameters
 880        ----------
 881        fileId : str
 882            name of exodus file to open
 883        include_transient: bool
 884            should the transient data in the original file also be copied to the output file
 885            or just the mesh (non-transient) portion.
 886
 887        Returns
 888        -------
 889        file_id: The file_id of the copied to file
 890
 891        """
 892        EXODUS_LIB.ex_copy(self.fileId, file_id)
 893        if include_transient:
 894            EXODUS_LIB.ex_copy_transient(self.fileId, file_id)
 895
 896        return file_id
 897
 898    def title(self):
 899        """
 900        get the database title
 901
 902        >>> title = exo.title()
 903
 904        Returns
 905        -------
 906        title : string
 907        """
 908        return self.Title.value.decode('utf8')
 909
 910    def version_num(self):
 911        """
 912        get exodus version number used to create the database
 913
 914        >>> version = exo.version_num()
 915
 916        Returns
 917        -------
 918        version : string
 919            representation of version number
 920        """
 921        return "%1.2f" % self.version.value
 922
 923    def put_info(self, Title, numDim, numNodes, numElem, numElemBlk,
 924                 numNodeSets, numSideSets):
 925        """
 926        Initialize static metadata for the database.
 927
 928        >>> status = exo.put_info(title, num_dims, num_nodes, num_elems,
 929        ...                      num_blocks, num_ns, num_ss)
 930
 931        Parameters
 932        ----------
 933        title : string
 934            database title
 935        num_dims : int
 936            number of model dimensions
 937        num_nodes : int
 938            number of model nodes
 939        num_elems : int
 940            number of model elements
 941        num_blocks : int
 942            number of model element blocks
 943        num_ns : int
 944            number of model node sets
 945        num_ss : int
 946            number of model side sets
 947
 948        Returns
 949        -------
 950        status : bool
 951            True = successful execution
 952
 953        """
 954        self.__ex_put_info([Title, numDim, numNodes, numElem,
 955                            numElemBlk, numNodeSets, numSideSets])
 956        return True
 957
 958    def inquire(self, inquiry):
 959        """
 960        Inquire about various properties of the database
 961
 962        Returns
 963        -------
 964        inq_res : int
 965        """
 966        return self.__ex_inquire_int(ex_inquiry_map(inquiry))
 967
 968    def num_qa_records(self):
 969        """
 970        get the number of qa records
 971
 972        >>> num_qa_recs = exo.num_qa_records()
 973
 974        Returns
 975        -------
 976        num_qa_recs : int
 977        """
 978        return int(self.__ex_inquire_int(ex_inquiry_map('EX_INQ_QA')))
 979
 980    def get_qa_records(self):
 981        """
 982        get a list of QA records where each QA record is a length-4 tuple of strings:
 983          1. the software name that accessed/modified the database
 984          2. the software descriptor, e.g. version
 985          3. additional software data
 986          4. time stamp
 987
 988        >>> qa_recs = exo.get_qa_records()
 989
 990
 991        Returns
 992        -------
 993        qa_recs : <list<tuple[4]<string>>>
 994        """
 995        return self.__ex_get_qa()
 996
 997    def put_qa_records(self, records):
 998        """
 999        store a list of QA records where each QA record is a length-4 tuple of strings:
1000          1. the software name that accessed/modified the database
1001          2. the software descriptor, e.g. version
1002          3. additional software data
1003          4. time stamp
1004
1005        >>> status = exo.put_qa_records()
1006
1007        Parameter
1008        ---------
1009        qa_recs : <list<tuple[4]<string>>>
1010
1011        Returns
1012        ------
1013        status : bool
1014            True = successful execution
1015        """
1016        for rec in records:
1017            assert len(rec) == 4
1018            for recEntry in rec:
1019                assert len(str(recEntry).encode('ascii')) < MAX_STR_LENGTH
1020        return self.__ex_put_qa(records)
1021
1022    def num_info_records(self):
1023        """
1024        get the number of info records
1025
1026        >>> num_info_recs = exo.num_info_records()
1027
1028        Returns
1029        -------
1030        num_info_recs : int
1031        """
1032        return int(self.__ex_inquire_int(ex_inquiry_map('EX_INQ_INFO')))
1033
1034    def get_info_records(self):
1035        """
1036        get a list info records where each entry in the list is one info
1037        record, e.g. a line of an input deck
1038
1039        >>> info_recs = exo.get_info_records()
1040
1041        Returns
1042        -------
1043        info_recs : <list<string>>
1044
1045        """
1046        return self.__ex_get_info_recs()
1047
1048    def put_info_records(self, info):
1049        """
1050        store a list of info records where each entry in the list is
1051        one line of info, e.g. a line of an input deck
1052
1053        >>> status = exo.put_info_records(info)
1054
1055        Parameters
1056        ----------
1057        info_recs : <list<tuple[4]<string>>>
1058
1059        Returns
1060        -------
1061        status : bool
1062            True = successful execution
1063        """
1064        for rec in info:
1065            if len(str(rec).encode('ascii')) > MAX_LINE_LENGTH:
1066                print("WARNING: max line length reached for one or more info records;")
1067                print(
1068                    "         info stored to exodus file is incomplete for these records")
1069                break
1070        return self.__ex_put_info_recs(info)
1071
1072    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1073
1074    def get_sierra_input(self, inpFileName=None):
1075        """
1076        parse sierra input deck from the info records if inp_file_name
1077        is passed the deck is written to this file; otherwise a list
1078        of input deck file lines is returned
1079
1080        >>> inp = exo.get_sierra_input(inpFileName=inp_file_name)
1081
1082        Parameters
1083        ----------
1084        inp_file_name : string, optional
1085           Name of text file where info records corresponding to the Sierra input deck will be written
1086
1087        Returns
1088        -------
1089        inp : list<string>
1090           lines if inp_file_name not provided; otherwise, an empty list
1091
1092        """
1093        info_recs = self.__ex_get_info_recs()
1094        sierra_inp = []
1095        begin = False
1096        for rec in info_recs:
1097            vals = rec.split()
1098            if not begin:  # have not reached Sierra block
1099                if len(vals) >= 2 and vals[0].lower() == "begin" and vals[1].lower() == "sierra":
1100                    begin = True
1101            if begin:  # inside Sierra block
1102                sierra_inp.append(rec)
1103                if len(rec) > MAX_LINE_LENGTH:
1104                    print(
1105                        "WARNING: max line length reached for one or more input lines;")
1106                    print("         input data might be incomplete for these lines")
1107                    break
1108                if len(vals) >= 2 and vals[0].lower() == "end" and vals[1].lower() == "sierra":
1109                    break  # end of Sierra block
1110
1111        if inpFileName:
1112            with open(inpFileName.encode('ascii'), "w") as fd:
1113                for fileLine in sierra_inp:
1114                    fd.write(fileLine + "\n")
1115            return []
1116
1117        return sierra_inp
1118
1119    #
1120    # time steps
1121    #
1122    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1123
1124    def num_times(self):
1125        """
1126        get the number of time steps
1127
1128        >>> num_times = exo.num_times()
1129
1130        Returns
1131        -------
1132        num_times : int
1133        """
1134        return self.numTimes.value
1135
1136    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1137
1138    def get_times(self):
1139        """
1140        get the time values
1141
1142        >>> time_vals = exo.get_times()
1143
1144        Returns
1145        -------
1146            if array_type == 'ctype' :
1147              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  time_vals
1148
1149            if array_type == 'numpy' :
1150              <np_array<double>>  time_vals
1151        """
1152        if self.numTimes.value == 0:
1153            self.times = []
1154        else:
1155            self.__ex_get_all_times()
1156        if self.use_numpy:
1157            self.times = ctype_to_numpy(self, self.times)
1158        return self.times
1159
1160    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1161
1162    def put_time(self, step, value):
1163        """
1164        store a new time
1165
1166        >>> exo.put_time(time_step, time_val)
1167
1168        Parameters
1169        ----------
1170        time_step : int
1171            time step index (1-based)
1172        time_val : float
1173            time value for this step
1174
1175        Returns
1176        -------
1177        status : bool
1178            True = successful execution
1179        """
1180        self.__ex_put_time(step, value)
1181        self.numTimes = ctypes.c_int(self.__ex_inquire_int(ex_inquiry_map('EX_INQ_TIME')))
1182        return True
1183
1184    #
1185    # coordinate system
1186    #
1187    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1188
1189    def num_dimensions(self):
1190        """
1191        get the number of model spatial dimensions
1192
1193        >>> num_dims = exo.num_dimensions()
1194
1195        Returns
1196        -------
1197        num_dims : <int
1198        """
1199        return self.numDim.value
1200
1201    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1202
1203    def get_coord_names(self):
1204        """
1205        get a list of length exo.num_dimensions() that has the name
1206        of each model coordinate direction, e.g. ['x', 'y', 'z']
1207
1208        >>> coord_names = exo.get_coord_names()
1209
1210        Returns
1211        -------
1212            <list<string>>  coord_names
1213        """
1214        return self.__ex_get_coord_names()
1215
1216    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1217
1218    def put_coord_names(self, names):
1219        """
1220        store a list of length exo.num_dimensions() that has the name
1221        of each model coordinate direction, e.g. ['x', 'y', 'z']
1222
1223        >>> exo.put_coord_names()
1224
1225        Parameters
1226        ----------
1227            <list<string>>  coord_names
1228        """
1229        self.__ex_put_coord_names(names)
1230
1231    #
1232    # nodes
1233    #
1234    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1235
1236    def num_nodes(self):
1237        """
1238        get the number of nodes in the model
1239
1240        >>> num_nodes = exo.num_nodes()
1241
1242        Returns
1243        -------
1244        num_nodes : int
1245        """
1246        return self.numNodes.value
1247
1248    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1249
1250    def get_coords(self):
1251        """
1252        get model coordinates of all nodes; for each coordinate
1253        direction, a length exo.num_nodes() list is returned
1254
1255        >>> x_coords, y_coords, z_coords = exo.get_coords()
1256
1257        Returns
1258        -------
1259
1260            if array_type == 'ctype':
1261              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  x_coords  global x-direction coordinates
1262              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  y_coords  global y-direction coordinates
1263              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  z_coords  global z-direction coordinates
1264
1265            if array_type == 'numpy':
1266              <np_array<double>>  x_coords  global x-direction coordinates
1267              <np_array<double>>  y_coords  global y-direction coordinates
1268              <np_array<double>>  z_coords  global z-direction coordinates
1269        """
1270        self.__ex_get_coord()
1271        if self.use_numpy:
1272            self.coordsX = ctype_to_numpy(self, self.coordsX)
1273            self.coordsY = ctype_to_numpy(self, self.coordsY)
1274            self.coordsZ = ctype_to_numpy(self, self.coordsZ)
1275        return self.coordsX, self.coordsY, self.coordsZ
1276
1277    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1278
1279    def get_coord(self, i):
1280        """
1281        get model coordinates of a single node
1282
1283        >>> x_coord, y_coord, z_coord = exo.get_coord(node_index)
1284
1285        Parameters
1286        ----------
1287        node_index : int
1288            the 1-based node index (indexing is from 1 to exo.num_nodes())
1289
1290        Returns
1291        -------
1292        x_coord : double
1293            global x-direction coordinate
1294        y_coord : double
1295            global y-direction coordinate
1296        z_coord : double
1297            global z-direction coordinate
1298
1299        Note:
1300        -----
1301        >>> x_coords, y_coords, z_coords = exo.get_coords()
1302        >>> x_coord = x_coords[node_index-1]
1303        >>> y_coord = y_coords[node_index-1]
1304        >>> z_coord = z_coords[node_index-1]
1305            ... is equivalent to ...
1306        >>> x_coord, y_coord, z_coord = exo.get_coords(node_index)
1307
1308        """
1309        listX, listY, listZ = self.__ex_get_partial_coord(i, 1)
1310        return listX[0], listY[0], listZ[0]
1311
1312    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1313
1314    def put_coords(self, xCoords, yCoords, zCoords):
1315        """
1316        store model coordinates of all nodes; for each coordinate
1317        direction, a length exo.num_nodes() list is input
1318
1319        >>> status = exo.put_coords(x_coords, y_coords, z_coords)
1320
1321        Parameters
1322        ----------
1323        x_coord : <list<float>>
1324            global x-direction coordinates
1325        y_coord : <list<float>>
1326            global y-direction coordinates
1327        z_coord : <list<float>>
1328            global z-direction coordinates
1329
1330        Returns
1331        -------
1332        status : bool
1333            True = successful execution
1334        """
1335        self.__ex_put_coord(xCoords, yCoords, zCoords)
1336        return True
1337
1338    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1339
1340    def get_node_num_map(self):
1341        """
1342        **DEPRECATED** use: `get_node_id_map()`
1343
1344        get mapping of exodus node index to user- or application-
1345        defined node id; node_id_map is ordered the same as the nodal
1346        coordinate arrays returned by exo.get_coords() -- this ordering
1347        follows the exodus node *INDEX* order, a 1-based system going
1348        from 1 to exo.num_nodes(); a user or application can optionally
1349        use a separate node *ID* numbering system, so the node_id_map
1350        points to the node *ID* for each node *INDEX*
1351
1352        >>> node_id_map = exo.get_node_num_map()
1353
1354        Returns
1355        -------
1356            <list<ctypes.c_int>>  node_id_map
1357        """
1358        return self.__ex_get_node_num_map()
1359
1360    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1361
1362    def put_node_id_map(self, id_map):
1363        """
1364        store mapping of exodus node index to user- or application-
1365        defined node id; node_id_map is ordered the same as the nodal
1366        coordinate arrays returned by exo.get_coords() -- this ordering
1367        follows the exodus node *INDEX* order, a 1-based system going
1368        from 1 to exo.num_nodes(); a user or application can optionally
1369        use a separate node *ID* numbering system, so the node_id_map
1370        points to the node *ID* for each node *INDEX*
1371
1372        >>> status = exo.put_node_id_map(node_id_map)
1373
1374        Parameters
1375        ----------
1376            <list<int>>  node_id_map
1377
1378        Returns
1379        -------
1380        status : bool
1381            True = successful execution
1382        """
1383        return self.__ex_put_id_map('EX_NODE_MAP', id_map)
1384
1385    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1386
1387    def get_node_variable_names(self):
1388        """
1389        get the list of nodal variable names in the model
1390
1391        >>> nvar_names = exo.get_node_variable_names()
1392
1393        Returns
1394        -------
1395              <list<string>>  nvar_names
1396        """
1397        if self.__ex_get_variable_param('EX_NODAL').value == 0:
1398            return []
1399        return self.__ex_get_variable_names('EX_NODAL')
1400
1401    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1402
1403    def get_node_variable_number(self):
1404        """
1405        get the number of nodal variables in the model
1406
1407        >>> num_nvars = exo.get_node_variable_number()
1408
1409        Returns
1410        -------
1411        num_nvars : int
1412        """
1413        return self.__ex_get_variable_param('EX_NODAL').value
1414
1415    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1416
1417    def set_node_variable_number(self, number):
1418        """
1419        update the number of nodal variables in the model
1420
1421        >>> status = exo.set_node_variable_number(num_nvars)
1422
1423        Parameters
1424        ----------
1425        num_nvars : int
1426
1427        Returns
1428        -------
1429        status : bool
1430            True = successful execution
1431        """
1432        self.__ex_put_variable_param('EX_NODAL', number)
1433        return True
1434
1435    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1436
1437    def put_node_variable_name(self, name, index):
1438        """
1439        add the name and index of a new nodal variable to the model;
1440        nodal variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_node_variable_number()
1441
1442        >>> status = exo.put_node_variable_name(nvar_name, nvar_index)
1443
1444        Parameters
1445        ----------
1446            <string>  nvar_name   name of new nodal variable
1447            <int>     nvar_index  1-based index of new nodal variable
1448
1449        Returns
1450        -------
1451        status : bool
1452            True = successful execution
1453
1454        Note:
1455        ----
1456        this method is often called within the following sequence:
1457
1458        >>> num_nvars = exo.get_node_variable_number()
1459        >>> new_nvar_index = num_nvars + 1
1460        >>> num_nvars += 1
1461        >>> exo.set_node_variable_number(num_nvars)
1462        >>> exo.put_node_variable_name("new_nvar_name", new_nvar_index)
1463        """
1464        NDvarNames = self.get_variable_names('EX_NODAL')
1465        if name in NDvarNames:
1466            print(f'WARNING: node variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
1467        if index > len(NDvarNames):
1468            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
1469        self.__ex_put_variable_name('EX_NODAL', index, name)
1470        return True
1471
1472    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1473
1474    def get_node_variable_values(self, name, step):
1475        """
1476        get list of nodal variable values for a nodal variable name
1477        and time step
1478
1479        >>> nvar_vals = exo.get_node_variable_values(nvar_name, time_step)
1480
1481        Parameters
1482        ----------
1483            <string>  nvar_name  name of nodal variable
1484            <int>     time_step  1-based index of time step
1485
1486        Returns
1487        -------
1488
1489            if array_type == 'ctype':
1490              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  nvar_vals
1491
1492            if array_type == 'numpy':
1493              <np_array<double>>  nvar_vals
1494        """
1495        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_NODAL')
1496        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
1497        numVals = self.num_nodes()
1498        values = self.__ex_get_var(step, 'EX_NODAL', var_id, 0, numVals)
1499        if self.use_numpy:
1500            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
1501        return values
1502
1503    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1504
1505    def get_partial_node_variable_values(self, name, step, start_index, num_nodes):
1506        """
1507        get partial list of nodal variable values for a nodal variable name
1508        and time step.  Start at node `node_index` (1-based) and return `num_nodes`
1509        from that point.
1510
1511        >>> nvar_vals = exo.get_partial_node_variable_values(nvar_name, time_step, 10, 100)
1512
1513        Parameters
1514        ----------
1515            <string>  nvar_name   name of nodal variable
1516            <int>     time_step   1-based index of time step
1517            <int>     start_index 1-based index of node to start returning data
1518            <int>     num_nodes   number of nodes to return data for.
1519
1520        Returns
1521        -------
1522
1523            if array_type == 'ctype':
1524              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  nvar_vals
1525
1526            if array_type == 'numpy':
1527              <np_array<double>>  nvar_vals
1528        """
1529        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_NODAL')
1530        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
1531        values = self.__ex_get_partial_var(step, 'EX_NODAL', var_id, 0, start_index, num_nodes)
1532        if self.use_numpy:
1533            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
1534        return values
1535
1536    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1537
1538    def put_node_variable_values(self, name, step, values):
1539        """
1540        store a list of nodal variable values for a nodal variable
1541        name and time step
1542
1543        >>> status = exo.put_node_variable_values(nvar_name, time_step, nvar_vals)
1544
1545        Parameters
1546        ----------
1547            <string>       nvar_name  name of nodal variable
1548            <int>          time_step  1-based index of time step
1549            <list<float>>  nvar_vals
1550
1551        Returns
1552        -------
1553        status : bool
1554            True = successful execution
1555        """
1556        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_NODAL')
1557        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
1558        numVals = self.num_nodes()
1559        self.__ex_put_var(step, 'EX_NODAL', var_id, 0, numVals, values)
1560        return True
1561
1562    #
1563    # elements
1564    #
1565    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1566
1567    def num_elems(self):
1568        """
1569        get the number of elements in the model
1570
1571        >>> num_elems = exo.num_elems()
1572
1573        Returns
1574        -------
1575        num_elems : int
1576        """
1577        return self.numElem.value
1578
1579    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1580
1581    def get_num_map(self, mapType, idx):
1582        """
1583        get user-defined map of exodus element/node/edge/face index to user- or
1584        application- defined element/node/edge/face values. Map values are arbitary integers
1585
1586        >>> elem_num_map = exo.get_num_map('EX_ELEM_MAP', 1)
1587
1588        Parameters
1589        ----------
1590            mapType   : ex_entity_type
1591                        type of map being queried ('EX_ELEM_MAP', 'EX_NODE_MAP', 'EX_FACE_MAP', 'EX_EDGE_MAP')
1592            idx       : int
1593                        which map to return (1-based).  Use `inquire(mapType)` to get number of maps stored on database.
1594        Returns
1595        -------
1596
1597            if array_type == 'ctype':
1598              <list<int>>  num_map
1599
1600            if array_type == 'numpy':
1601              <np_array<int>>  num_map
1602
1603
1604        Usage
1605        -----
1606        >>> em_cnt = exo.inquire('EX_INQ_ELEM_MAP')
1607        >>> em     = exo.get_names('EX_ELEM_MAP')
1608        >>> map    = exo.get_num_map('EX_ELEM_MAP', 2)
1609
1610        """
1611        return self.__ex_get_num_map(mapType, idx)
1612
1613    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1614
1615    def put_num_map(self, mapType, idx, num_map):
1616        """
1617        put user-defined map of exodus element/node/edge/face index to user- or
1618        application- defined element/node/edge/face values. Map values are arbitary integers
1619
1620
1621        Parameters
1622        ----------
1623            mapType   : ex_entity_type
1624                        type of map being written ('EX_ELEM_MAP', 'EX_NODE_MAP', 'EX_FACE_MAP', 'EX_EDGE_MAP')
1625            idx       : int
1626                        which map to write (1-based).  Use `put_map_param(node_map_cnt, elem_map_cnt)` prior to this
1627                        function to define number of maps on the database.
1628            <list<int>>  elem_id_map
1629
1630
1631        Usage
1632        -----
1633
1634        >>> exo.put_map_param(nm_cnt, em_cnt)
1635        >>> nm[0] = "My_Node_Map"
1636        >>> exo.put_names('EX_NODE_MAP', nm);
1637        >>> exo.put_num_map('EX_NODE_MAP', 1, scale_map)
1638
1639        """
1640        return self.__ex_put_num_map(mapType, idx, num_map)
1641
1642    def put_map_param(self, node_map_cnt, elem_map_cnt):
1643        """
1644        Define number of node and element maps that will be written to the database
1645
1646        Parameters
1647        ----------
1648        node_map_cnt  : int
1649                        number of node maps
1650        elem_map_cnt  : int
1651                        number of element maps
1652
1653        """
1654        return self.__ex_put_map_param(node_map_cnt, elem_map_cnt)
1655
1656    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1657
1658    def get_id_map(self, mapType):
1659        """
1660        get mapping of exodus element/node/edge/face index to user- or
1661        application- defined element/node/edge/face id; id_map is ordered by the
1662        *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to
1663        exo.num_???s(), used by exodus for storage and input/output
1664        of array data stored on the elements/nodes/edges/faces; a user or application
1665        can optionally use a separate *ID* numbering system,
1666        so the id_map points to the element/node/edge/face *ID* for each
1667        *INDEX*
1668
1669        >>> elem_id_map = exo.get_id_map('EX_ELEM_MAP')
1670
1671        Parameters
1672        ----------
1673            mapType   : ex_entity_type
1674                        type of map being queried ('EX_ELEM_MAP', 'EX_NODE_MAP', 'EX_FACE_MAP', 'EX_EDGE_MAP')
1675        Returns
1676        -------
1677
1678            if array_type == 'ctype':
1679              <list<int>>  id_map
1680
1681            if array_type == 'numpy':
1682              <np_array<int>>  id_map
1683
1684        """
1685        return self.__ex_get_id_map(mapType)
1686
1687    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1688
1689    def get_elem_id_map(self):
1690        """
1691        get mapping of exodus element index to user- or application-
1692        defined element id; elem_id_map is ordered by the element
1693        *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to
1694        exo.num_elems(), used by exodus for storage and input/output
1695        of array data stored on the elements; a user or application
1696        can optionally use a separate element *ID* numbering system,
1697        so the elem_id_map points to the element *ID* for each
1698        element *INDEX*
1699
1700        >>> elem_id_map = exo.get_elem_id_map()
1701
1702        Returns
1703        -------
1704
1705            if array_type == 'ctype':
1706              <list<int>>  elem_id_map
1707
1708            if array_type == 'numpy':
1709              <np_array<int>>  elem_id_map
1710        """
1711        return self.__ex_get_id_map('EX_ELEM_MAP')
1712
1713    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1714
1715    def put_elem_id_map(self, id_map):
1716        """
1717        store mapping of exodus element index to user- or application-
1718        defined element id; elem_id_map is ordered by the element
1719        *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to
1720        exo.num_elems(), used by exodus for storage and input/output
1721        of array data stored on the elements; a user or application
1722        can optionally use a separate element *ID* numbering system,
1723        so the elem_id_map points to the element *ID* for each
1724        element *INDEX*
1725
1726        >>> status = exo.put_elem_id_map(elem_id_map)
1727
1728        Parameters
1729        ----------
1730            <list<int>>  elem_id_map
1731
1732        Returns
1733        -------
1734        status : bool
1735            True = successful execution
1736        """
1737        return self.__ex_put_id_map('EX_ELEM_MAP', id_map)
1738
1739    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1740
1741    def put_id_map(self, map_type, id_map):
1742        """
1743        store mapping of exodus entity index to user- or application-
1744        defined entity id; id_map is ordered by the entity
1745        *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to
1746        exo.num_XXX(), used by exodus for storage and input/output
1747        of array data stored on the entities; a user or application
1748        can optionally use a separate entity *ID* numbering system,
1749        so the elem_id_map points to the entity *ID* for each
1750        entity *INDEX*
1751
1752        >>> status = exo.put_id_map('EX_ELEM_MAP', elem_id_map)
1753
1754        Parameters
1755        ----------
1756            ex_entity_type   map_type
1757                        type of map being queried ('EX_ELEM_MAP', 'EX_NODE_MAP', 'EX_FACE_MAP', 'EX_EDGE_MAP')
1758            <list<int>>  elem_id_map
1759
1760        Returns
1761        -------
1762        status : bool
1763            True = successful execution
1764        """
1765        return self.__ex_put_id_map(map_type, id_map)
1766
1767    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1768
1769    def get_block_id_map(self, obj_type, entity_id):
1770        """
1771        Gets the map of elements found in the given entity_id of an object
1772        of obj_type.
1773
1774        *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to
1775        number of elements in the elem_block, used by exodus for
1776        storage and input/output of array data stored on the elements;
1777        a user or application can optionally use a separate element *ID* numbering system,
1778        so the elem_id_map points to the element *ID* for each
1779        element *INDEX*
1780
1781        >>> elem_block_id_map = exo.get_block_id_map("EX_ELEM_BLOCK", 100)
1782
1783        Returns
1784        -------
1785
1786            if array_type == 'ctype':
1787              <list<int>>  elem_id_map
1788
1789            if array_type == 'numpy':
1790              <np_array<int>>  elem_id_map
1791        """
1792        return self.__ex_get_block_id_map(obj_type, entity_id)
1793
1794    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1795
1796    def get_elem_num_map(self):
1797        """
1798        **DEPRECATED** use: `get_elem_id_map()`
1799
1800        get mapping of exodus element index to user- or application-
1801        defined element id; elem_id_map is ordered by the element
1802        *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to
1803        exo.num_elems(), used by exodus for storage and input/output
1804        of array data stored on the elements; a user or application
1805        can optionally use a separate element *ID* numbering system,
1806        so the elem_id_map points to the element *ID* for each
1807        element *INDEX*
1808
1809        >>> elem_id_map = exo.get_elem_num_map()
1810
1811        Returns
1812        -------
1813            <list<ctypes.c_int>>  elem_id_map
1814        """
1815        return self.__ex_get_elem_num_map()
1816
1817    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1818
1819    def get_elem_order_map(self):
1820        """
1821        get mapping of exodus element index to application-defined
1822        optimal ordering; elem_order_map is ordered by the element
1823        index ordering used by exodus for storage and input/output
1824        of array data stored on the elements; a user or application
1825        can optionally use a separate element ordering, e.g. for
1826        optimal solver performance, so the elem_order_map points to
1827        the index used by the application for each exodus element
1828        index
1829
1830        >>> elem_order_map = exo.get_elem_order_map()
1831
1832        Returns
1833        -------
1834
1835            if array_type == 'ctype':
1836              <list<int>>  elem_order_map
1837
1838            if array_type == 'numpy':
1839              <np_array<int>>  elem_order_map
1840        """
1841
1842        elemOrderMap = self.__ex_get_elem_order_map()
1843        if self.use_numpy:
1844            elemOrderMap = ctype_to_numpy(self, elemOrderMap)
1845        return elemOrderMap
1846
1847    # Generic (objType) get/put/query...
1848    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1849
1850    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1851
1852    def get_node_id_map(self):
1853        """
1854        get mapping of exodus node index to user- or application-
1855        defined node id; node_id_map is ordered the same as the nodal
1856        coordinate arrays returned by exo.get_coords() -- this ordering
1857        follows the exodus node *INDEX* order, a 1-based system going
1858        from 1 to exo.num_nodes(); a user or application can optionally
1859        use a separate node *ID* numbering system, so the node_id_map
1860        points to the node *ID* for each node *INDEX*
1861
1862        >>> node_id_map = exo.get_node_id_map()
1863
1864        Returns
1865        -------
1866
1867            if array_type == 'ctype':
1868              <list<int>>  node_id_map
1869
1870            if array_type == 'numpy':
1871              <np_array<int>>  node_id_map
1872        """
1873        return self.__ex_get_id_map('EX_NODE_MAP')
1874
1875    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1876
1877    def get_name(self, object_type, object_id):
1878        """
1879        get the name of the specified entity_type and entity
1880
1881        >>> elem_blk_name = exo.get_name('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id)
1882
1883        Parameters
1884        ----------
1885        object_type : int
1886            block/set type
1887        object_id : int
1888            block/set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
1889
1890        Returns
1891        -------
1892        name : string
1893        """
1894        return self.__ex_get_name(object_type, object_id)
1895
1896    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1897
1898    def put_name(self, object_type, object_id, name):
1899        """
1900        put the name of the specified entity_type and entity
1901
1902        >>> exo.put_name('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id, block_name)
1903
1904        Parameters
1905        ----------
1906        object_type : int
1907            block/set type
1908        object_id : int
1909            block/set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
1910        name : string
1911            block/set name
1912
1913        Returns
1914        -------
1915        elem_blk_name : string
1916        """
1917        self.__ex_put_name(object_type, object_id, name)
1918
1919    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1920
1921    def get_names(self, object_type):
1922        """
1923        get a list of all block/set names ordered by block/set *INDEX*;
1924        (see `exodus.get_ids` for explanation of the
1925        difference between *ID* and *INDEX*)
1926
1927        >>> blk_names = exo.get_names('EX_ELEM_BLOCK')
1928
1929        Parameters
1930        ----------
1931        object_type : int
1932            block/set type
1933
1934        Returns
1935        -------
1936            <list<string>>  names
1937        """
1938        return self.__ex_get_names(object_type)
1939
1940    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1941
1942    def put_names(self, object_type, names):
1943        """
1944        store a list of all block/set names of the specified
1945        `object_type` ordered by *INDEX*;
1946        (see `exodus.get_ids` for explanation of the
1947        difference between *ID* and *INDEX*)
1948
1949        >>> exo.put_names('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_names)
1950
1951        Parameters
1952        ----------
1953        object_type : int
1954        names : <list<string>>
1955        """
1956
1957        self.__ex_put_names(object_type, names)
1958
1959    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1960
1961    def get_reduction_variable_values(self, objType, id, step):
1962        """
1963        get list of reduction variable values for a specified entity type and
1964        id, and time step
1965
1966        >>> evar_vals = exo.get_reduction_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id, time_step)
1967
1968        Parameters
1969        ----------
1970        objType   : ex_entity_type
1971            type of object being queried
1972        id        : int
1973            entity *ID* (not *INDEX*)
1974        time_step : int
1975            1-based index of time step
1976
1977        Returns
1978        -------
1979
1980            if array_type == 'ctype':
1981              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals
1982
1983            if array_type == 'numpy':
1984              <np_array<double>>  evar_vals
1985
1986        """
1987        numVals = self.get_reduction_variable_number(objType)
1988        values = self.__ex_get_reduction_vars(step, objType, id, numVals)
1989        if self.use_numpy:
1990            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
1991        return values
1992
1993    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
1994
1995    def put_reduction_variable_values(self, objType, id, step, values):
1996        """
1997        store a list of 'objType' variable values for a specified entity,
1998        and time step
1999
2000        >>> status = exo.put_redcution_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id,
2001        ...             time_step, evar_vals)
2002
2003        Parameters
2004        ----------
2005        objType : ex_entity_type
2006            type of object begin queried
2007        id : int
2008            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2009            <int>          time_step    1-based index of time step
2010            <list<float>>  evar_vals
2011
2012        Returns
2013        -------
2014        status : bool
2015            True = successful execution
2016        """
2017        numVals = self.get_reduction_variable_number(objType)
2018        self.__ex_put_reduction_vars(step, objType, id, numVals, values)
2019        return True
2020
2021    # --------------------------------------------------------------------
2022
2023    def get_ids(self, objType):
2024        """
2025        get mapping of exodus block/set index to user- or application-
2026        defined block/set id; ids is ordered
2027        by the *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from
2028        1 to number_set_or_block, used by exodus for storage
2029        and input/output of array data stored on the blocks/sets; a
2030        user or application can optionally use a separate block/set
2031        *ID* numbering system, so the ids array points to the
2032        block/set *ID* for each set *INDEX*
2033
2034        >>> node_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')
2035
2036        Returns
2037        -------
2038
2039            if array_type == 'ctype':
2040              <list<int>>  ids
2041
2042            if array_type == 'numpy':
2043              <np_array<int>>  ids
2044        """
2045        ids = self.__ex_get_ids(objType)
2046        if self.use_numpy:
2047            ids = self.np.array(ids)
2048        return ids
2049
