def get_elem_order_map(self): 
1820    def get_elem_order_map(self):
1821        """
1822        get mapping of exodus element index to application-defined
1823        optimal ordering; elem_order_map is ordered by the element
1824        index ordering used by exodus for storage and input/output
1825        of array data stored on the elements; a user or application
1826        can optionally use a separate element ordering, e.g. for
1827        optimal solver performance, so the elem_order_map points to
1828        the index used by the application for each exodus element
1829        index
1830
1831        >>> elem_order_map = exo.get_elem_order_map()
1832
1833        Returns
1834        -------
1835
1836            if array_type == 'ctype':
1837              <list<int>>  elem_order_map
1838
1839            if array_type == 'numpy':
1840              <np_array<int>>  elem_order_map
1841        """
1842
1843        elemOrderMap = self.__ex_get_elem_order_map()
1844        if self.use_numpy:
1845            elemOrderMap = ctype_to_numpy(self, elemOrderMap)
1846        return elemOrderMap

get mapping of exodus element index to application-defined optimal ordering; elem_order_map is ordered by the element index ordering used by exodus for storage and input/output of array data stored on the elements; a user or application can optionally use a separate element ordering, e.g. for optimal solver performance, so the elem_order_map points to the index used by the application for each exodus element index

>>> elem_order_map = exo.get_elem_order_map()

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  elem_order_map

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  elem_order_map
def get_node_id_map(self): 
1853    def get_node_id_map(self):
1854        """
1855        get mapping of exodus node index to user- or application-
1856        defined node id; node_id_map is ordered the same as the nodal
1857        coordinate arrays returned by exo.get_coords() -- this ordering
1858        follows the exodus node *INDEX* order, a 1-based system going
1859        from 1 to exo.num_nodes(); a user or application can optionally
1860        use a separate node *ID* numbering system, so the node_id_map
1861        points to the node *ID* for each node *INDEX*
1862
1863        >>> node_id_map = exo.get_node_id_map()
1864
1865        Returns
1866        -------
1867
1868            if array_type == 'ctype':
1869              <list<int>>  node_id_map
1870
1871            if array_type == 'numpy':
1872              <np_array<int>>  node_id_map
1873        """
1874        return self.__ex_get_id_map('EX_NODE_MAP')

get mapping of exodus node index to user- or application- defined node id; node_id_map is ordered the same as the nodal coordinate arrays returned by exo.get_coords() -- this ordering follows the exodus node INDEX order, a 1-based system going from 1 to exo.num_nodes(); a user or application can optionally use a separate node ID numbering system, so the node_id_map points to the node ID for each node INDEX

>>> node_id_map = exo.get_node_id_map()

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  node_id_map

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  node_id_map

def get_reduction_variable_values(self, objType, id, step): 
1962    def get_reduction_variable_values(self, objType, id, step):
1963        """
1964        get list of reduction variable values for a specified entity type and
1965        id, and time step
1966
1967        >>> evar_vals = exo.get_reduction_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id, time_step)
1968
1969        Parameters
1970        ----------
1971        objType   : ex_entity_type
1972            type of object being queried
1973        id        : int
1974            entity *ID* (not *INDEX*)
1975        time_step : int
1976            1-based index of time step
1977
1978        Returns
1979        -------
1980
1981            if array_type == 'ctype':
1982              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals
1983
1984            if array_type == 'numpy':
1985              <np_array<double>>  evar_vals
1986
1987        """
1988        numVals = self.get_reduction_variable_number(objType)
1989        values = self.__ex_get_reduction_vars(step, objType, id, numVals)
1990        if self.use_numpy:
1991            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
1992        return values

get list of reduction variable values for a specified entity type and id, and time step

>>> evar_vals = exo.get_reduction_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id, time_step)

Parameters

objType : ex_entity_type type of object being queried id : int entity ID (not INDEX) time_step : int 1-based index of time step

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<double>>  evar_vals
def put_reduction_variable_values(self, objType, id, step, values): 
1996    def put_reduction_variable_values(self, objType, id, step, values):
1997        """
1998        store a list of 'objType' variable values for a specified entity,
1999        and time step
2000
2001        >>> status = exo.put_redcution_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id,
2002        ...             time_step, evar_vals)
2003
2004        Parameters
2005        ----------
2006        objType : ex_entity_type
2007            type of object begin queried
2008        id : int
2009            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2010            <int>          time_step    1-based index of time step
2011            <list<float>>  evar_vals
2012
2013        Returns
2014        -------
2015        status : bool
2016            True = successful execution
2017        """
2018        numVals = self.get_reduction_variable_number(objType)
2019        self.__ex_put_reduction_vars(step, objType, id, numVals, values)
2020        return True

status : bool True = successful execution

def get_ids(self, objType): 
2024    def get_ids(self, objType):
2025        """
2026        get mapping of exodus block/set index to user- or application-
2027        defined block/set id; ids is ordered
2028        by the *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from
2029        1 to number_set_or_block, used by exodus for storage
2030        and input/output of array data stored on the blocks/sets; a
2031        user or application can optionally use a separate block/set
2032        *ID* numbering system, so the ids array points to the
2033        block/set *ID* for each set *INDEX*
2034
2035        >>> node_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')
2036
2037        Returns
2038        -------
2039
2040            if array_type == 'ctype':
2041              <list<int>>  ids
2042
2043            if array_type == 'numpy':
2044              <np_array<int>>  ids
2045        """
2046        ids = self.__ex_get_ids(objType)
2047        if self.use_numpy:
2048            ids = self.np.array(ids)
2049        return ids

get mapping of exodus block/set index to user- or application- defined block/set id; ids is ordered by the INDEX ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to number_set_or_block, used by exodus for storage and input/output of array data stored on the blocks/sets; a user or application can optionally use a separate block/set ID numbering system, so the ids array points to the block/set ID for each set INDEX

>>> node_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  ids

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  ids
def get_variable_truth_table(self, objType, entId=None): 
2052    def get_variable_truth_table(self, objType, entId=None):
2053        """
2054        gets a truth table indicating which variables are defined for
2055        specified entity type; if entId is not passed, then a concatenated
2056        truth table for all entities is returned with variable index
2057        cycling faster than entity index
2058
2059        >>> ssvar_truth_tab = exo.get_variable_truth_table('EX_SIDE_SET', sideSetID=side_set_id)
2060
2061        Parameters
2062        ----------
2063        entId : int, optional
2064            entity *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2065
2066        Returns
2067        -------
2068        truth_tab : <list<bool>>
2069            True for variable defined in an entity, False otherwise
2070        """
2071        if entId is None:
2072            return self.__ex_get_truth_table(objType)
2073        else:
2074            return self.__ex_get_object_truth_vector(objType, entId)

gets a truth table indicating which variables are defined for specified entity type; if entId is not passed, then a concatenated truth table for all entities is returned with variable index cycling faster than entity index

>>> ssvar_truth_tab = exo.get_variable_truth_table('EX_SIDE_SET', sideSetID=side_set_id)

Parameters

entId : int, optional entity ID (not INDEX)

Returns

truth_tab : > True for variable defined in an entity, False otherwise

def set_variable_truth_table(self, objType, table): 
2078    def set_variable_truth_table(self, objType, table):
2079        """
2080        stores a truth table indicating which variables are defined for
2081        all sets/blocks of the specified `objType` and all variables; variable index cycles
2082        faster than entity index
2083
2084        >>> status = exo.set_variable_truth_table('EX_NODE_SET', nsvar_truth_tab)
2085
2086        Parameters
2087        ----------
2088        table : <list<bool>>
2089            True for variable defined in a node set, False otherwise
2090
2091        Returns
2092        -------
2093        status : bool
2094            True = successful execution
2095        """
2096        return self.__ex_put_truth_table(objType, table)

def get_variable_names(self, objType): 
2100    def get_variable_names(self, objType):
2101        """

2103

2105
2106        Returns
2107        -------
2108              <list<string>>  nvar_names
2109        """
2110        if self.__ex_get_variable_param(objType).value == 0:
2111            return []
2112        return self.__ex_get_variable_names(objType)

def put_variable_name(self, objType, name, index): 
2216    def put_variable_name(self, objType, name, index):
2217        """
2218        add the name and index of a new variable to the model;
2219        variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_variable_number()
2220
2221        >>> status = exo.put_variable_name('EX_NODAL', nvar_name, nvar_index)
2222
2223        Parameters
2224        ----------
2225        objType : string
2226            object type
2227        var_name : string
2228            name of new variable
2229        nvar_index : int
2230            1-based index of new nodal variable
2231
2232        Returns
2233        -------
2234        status : bool
2235            True = successful execution
2236
2237        Note:
2238        ----
2239        this method is often called within the following sequence:
2240
2241        >>> num_nvars = exo.get_variable_number('EX_NODAL')
2242        >>> new_nvar_index = num_nvars + 1
2243        >>> num_nvars += 1
2244        >>> exo.set_variable_number('EX_NODAL', num_nvars)
2245        >>> exo.put_variable_name('EX_NODAL', "new_nvar_name", new_nvar_index)
2246        """
2247        varNames = self.get_variable_names(objType)
2248        if name in varNames:
2249            print(f'WARNING: variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
2250        if index > len(varNames):
2251            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
2252        self.__ex_put_variable_name(objType, index, name)
2253        return True

add the name and index of a new variable to the model; variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_variable_number()

>>> status = exo.put_variable_name('EX_NODAL', nvar_name, nvar_index)

Parameters

objType : string object type var_name : string name of new variable nvar_index : int 1-based index of new nodal variable

Returns

status : bool True = successful execution

Note:

this method is often called within the following sequence:

>>> num_nvars = exo.get_variable_number('EX_NODAL')
>>> new_nvar_index = num_nvars + 1
>>> num_nvars += 1
>>> exo.set_variable_number('EX_NODAL', num_nvars)
>>> exo.put_variable_name('EX_NODAL', "new_nvar_name", new_nvar_index)
def put_reduction_variable_name(self, objType, name, index): 
2257    def put_reduction_variable_name(self, objType, name, index):
2258        """
2259        add the name and index of a new reduction variable to the model;
2260        variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_reductino_variable_number()
2261
2262        >>> status = exo.put_reduction_variable_name('EX_ASSEMBLY', assemvar_name, assemvar_index)
2263
2264        Parameters
2265        ----------
2266        objType : string
2267            object type
2268        var_name : string
2269            name of new variable
2270        nvar_index : int
2271            1-based index of new nodal variable
2272
2273        Returns
2274        -------
2275        status : bool
2276            True = successful execution
2277
2278        Note:
2279        ----
2280        this method is often called within the following sequence:
2281
2282        >>> num_assem_vars = exo.get_reduction_variable_number('EX_ASSEMBLY')
2283        >>> new_assem_var_index = num_assem_vars + 1
2284        >>> num_assem_vars += 1
2285        >>> exo.set_reduction_variable_number('EX_ASSEMBLY', num_assem_vars)
2286        >>> exo.put_reduction_variable_name('EX_ASSEMBLY', "new_assem_var_name", new_assem_var_index)
2287        """
2288        varNames = self.get_reduction_variable_names(objType)
2289        if name in varNames:
2290            print(f'WARNING: variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
2291        if index > len(varNames):
2292            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
2293        self.__ex_put_reduction_variable_name(objType, index, name)
2294        return True

status : bool True = successful execution

>>> num_assem_vars = exo.get_reduction_variable_number('EX_ASSEMBLY')
>>> new_assem_var_index = num_assem_vars + 1
>>> num_assem_vars += 1
>>> exo.set_reduction_variable_number('EX_ASSEMBLY', num_assem_vars)
>>> exo.put_reduction_variable_name('EX_ASSEMBLY', "new_assem_var_name", new_assem_var_index)
def get_entity_count(self, objType, entityId): 
2296    def get_entity_count(self, objType, entityId):
2297        """
2298        get number of nodes/elements in the specified set/block. Typically used internally
2299        by other user-callable functions.
2300
2301        Parameters
2302        ----------
2303        objType   : ex_entity_type
2304            type of object being queried
2305        entityId : int
2306            id of the entity (block, set) *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2307        """
2308
2309        numVals = 0
2310        if objType == "EX_NODAL":
2311            numVals = self.num_nodes()
2312        elif objType in ['EX_ELEM_BLOCK', 'EX_FACE_BLOCK', 'EX_EDGE_BLOCK']:
2313            (_elemType, numVals, _nodesPerElem, _numAttr) = self.__ex_get_block(objType, entityId)
2314        elif objType in ['EX_NODE_SET', 'EX_EDGE_SET', 'EX_FACE_SET', 'EX_SIDE_SET']:
2315            (numVals, _numDistFactInSet) = self.__ex_get_set_param(objType, entityId)
2316
2317        return numVals

get number of nodes/elements in the specified set/block. Typically used internally by other user-callable functions.

Parameters

objType : ex_entity_type type of object being queried entityId : int id of the entity (block, set) ID (not INDEX)

def get_variable_values(self, objType, entityId, name, step): 
2319    def get_variable_values(self, objType, entityId, name, step):
2320        """
2321        get list of `objType` variable values for a specified object id
2322        block, variable name, and time step
2323
2324        >>> evar_vals = exo.get_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id,
2325        ...                                            evar_name, time_step)
2326
2327        Parameters
2328        ----------
2329        objType   : ex_entity_type
2330            type of object being queried
2331        entityId : int
2332            id of the entity (block, set) *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2333        name : string
2334            name of variable
2335        time_step : int
2336            1-based index of time step
2337
2338        Returns
2339        -------
2340
2341            if array_type == 'ctype':
2342              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals
2343
2344            if array_type == 'numpy':
2345              <np_array<double>>  evar_vals
2346        """
2347        names = self.get_variable_names(objType)
2348        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
2349        numVals = self.get_entity_count(objType, entityId)
2350
2351        values = self.__ex_get_var(step, objType, var_id, entityId, numVals)
2352        if self.use_numpy:
2353            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
2354        return values

get list of objType variable values for a specified object id block, variable name, and time step

>>> evar_vals = exo.get_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id,
...                                            evar_name, time_step)

Parameters

objType : ex_entity_type type of object being queried entityId : int id of the entity (block, set) ID (not INDEX) name : string name of variable time_step : int 1-based index of time step

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<double>>  evar_vals
def put_variable_values(self, objType, entityId, name, step, values): 
2356    def put_variable_values(self, objType, entityId, name, step, values):
2357        """
2358        store a list of element variable values for a specified element
2359        block, element variable name, and time step
2360
2361        >>> status = exo.put_variable_values('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id,
2362        ...             evar_name, time_step, evar_vals)
2363
2364        Parameters
2365        ----------
2366        entityId : int  entity *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2367            <string>    name    name of variable
2368            <int>          time_step    1-based index of time step
2369            <list<float>>  values the variable values to be output
2370
2371        Returns
2372        -------
2373        status : bool
2374            True = successful execution
2375        """
2376        names = self.get_variable_names(objType)
2377        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
2378        numVals = self.get_entity_count(objType, entityId)
2379
2380        self.__ex_put_var(step, objType, var_id, entityId, numVals, values)
2381        return True

<int>  num_assembly
def get_assembly(self, object_id): 
2440    def get_assembly(self, object_id):
2441        """
2442        reads the assembly parameters and assembly data for one assembly
2443        """
2444        assem = ex_assembly(id=object_id)
2445        self.__ex_get_assembly(assem)
2446        assmbly = assembly(assem.name.decode('utf8'), assem.id, assem.type)
2447        for j in range(assem.entity_count):
2448            assmbly.entity_list.append(assem.entity_list[j])
2449        return assmbly

reads the assembly parameters and assembly data for one assembly

def get_assemblies(self, object_ids): 
2451    def get_assemblies(self, object_ids):
2452        """
2453        reads the assembly parameters and assembly data for all assemblies
2454        with ids in object_ids
2455        """
2456        assemblies = [ex_assembly(id=object_id) for object_id in object_ids]
2457        assems = (ex_assembly * len(assemblies))(*assemblies)
2458        self.__ex_get_assemblies(assems)
2459        assembs = [assembly(assem.name.decode('utf8'), assem.id, assem.type) for assem in
2460                   assems]
2461        for i, a in enumerate(assems):
2462            for j in range(a.entity_count):
2463                assembs[i].entity_list.append(a.entity_list[j])
2464        return assembs

reads the assembly parameters and assembly data for all assemblies with ids in object_ids

def get_elem_blk_ids(self): 
2510    def get_elem_blk_ids(self):
2511        """
2512        get mapping of exodus element block index to user- or
2513        application-defined element block id; elem_blk_ids is ordered
2514        by the element block *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going
2515        from 1 to exo.num_blks(), used by exodus for storage
2516        and input/output of array data stored on the element blocks; a
2517        user or application can optionally use a separate element block
2518        *ID* numbering system, so the elem_blk_ids array points to the
2519        element block *ID* for each element block *INDEX*
2520
2521        >>> elem_blk_ids = exo.get_elem_blk_ids()
2522
2523        Returns
2524        -------
2525
2526            if array_type == 'ctype':
2527              <list<int>>  elem_blk_ids
2528
2529            if array_type == 'numpy':
2530              <np_array<int>>  elem_blk_ids
2531        """
2532        return self.get_ids('EX_ELEM_BLOCK')

get mapping of exodus element block index to user- or application-defined element block id; elem_blk_ids is ordered by the element block INDEX ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to exo.num_blks(), used by exodus for storage and input/output of array data stored on the element blocks; a user or application can optionally use a separate element block ID numbering system, so the elem_blk_ids array points to the element block ID for each element block INDEX

>>> elem_blk_ids = exo.get_elem_blk_ids()

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  elem_blk_ids

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  elem_blk_ids

def elem_blk_info(self, object_id): 
2593    def elem_blk_info(self, object_id):
2594        """
2595        get the element block info
2596
2597        >>> elem_type, num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs
2598        ...       = exo.elem_blk_info(elem_blk_id)
2599
2600        Parameters
2601        ----------
2602        elem_blk_id : int
2603            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2604
2605        Returns
2606        -------
2607            <string>  elem_type       element type, e.g. 'HEX8'
2608            <int>     num_blk_elems   number of elements in the block
2609            <int>     num_elem_nodes  number of nodes per element
2610            <int>     num_elem_attrs  number of attributes per element
2611        """
2612        (elemType, numElem, nodesPerElem, numAttr) = self.__ex_get_block('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', object_id)
2613        return elemType, numElem, nodesPerElem, numAttr

def put_elem_blk_info( self, elem_blk_id, elem_type, num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs):

2616                          num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs):

2618        store the element block *ID* and element block info
2619

2621        ...                      num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs)

2626            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2627        elem_type : string

2631        num_elem_nodes : int
2632            number of nodes per element
2633        num_elem_attrs : int

def put_concat_elem_blk( self, elem_blk_ids, elem_type, num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs, defineMaps): 
2639    def put_concat_elem_blk(self, elem_blk_ids, elem_type, num_blk_elems,
2640                            num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs, defineMaps):
2641        """
2642        same as exo.put_elem_blk_info() but for all blocks at once
2643
2644        >>> status = exo.put_concat_elem_blk(elem_blk_ids, elem_types,
2645        ...                                 num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs)
2646
2647        Parameters
2648        ----------
2649            <list<int>>     elem_blk_ids     element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2650              for each block
2651            <list<string>>  elem_types       element type for each block
2652            <list<int>>     num_blk_elems    number of elements for each
2653              block
2654            <list<int>>     num_elem_nodes   number of nodes per element
2655              for each block
2656            <list<int>>     num_elem_attrs   number of attributes per
2657              element for each block
2658
2659        Returns
2660        -------
2661        status : bool
2662            True = successful execution
2663        """
2664        self.__ex_put_concat_elem_blk(
2665            elem_blk_ids,
2666            elem_type,
2667            num_blk_elems,
2668            num_elem_nodes,
2669            num_elem_attrs,
2670            defineMaps)
2671        return True

...                                 num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes, num_elem_attrs)

  block

  element for each block

def get_elem_connectivity(self, object_id): 
2673    def get_elem_connectivity(self, object_id):
2674        """
2675        get the nodal connectivity, number of elements, and
2676        number of nodes per element for a single block
2677
2678        >>> elem_conn, num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes
2679        ...        = exo.get_elem_connectivity(elem_blk_id)
2680
2681        Parameters
2682        ----------
2683        elem_blk_id : int
2684            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2685
2686        Returns
2687        -------
2688
2689            if array_type == 'ctype':
2690              <list<int>>  elem_conn  ordered list of node *INDICES* that
2691                define the connectivity of each element
2692                in the block; the list cycles through
2693                all nodes of the first element, then
2694                all nodes of the second element, etc.
2695                (see `exodus.get_id_map` for explanation
2696                of node *INDEX* versus node *ID*)
2697
2698            if array_type == 'numpy':
2699              <np_array<int>>  elem_conn  (same description)
2700
2701            <int>  num_blk_elems    number of elements in the block
2702            <int>  num_elem_nodes   number of nodes per element
2703        """
2704        (elem_block_connectivity, num_elem_this_blk,
2705         num_nodes_per_elem) = self.__ex_get_elem_conn(object_id)
2706        if self.use_numpy:
2707            elem_block_connectivity = ctype_to_numpy(
2708                self, elem_block_connectivity)
2709        return elem_block_connectivity, num_elem_this_blk, num_nodes_per_elem

get the nodal connectivity, number of elements, and number of nodes per element for a single block

>>> elem_conn, num_blk_elems, num_elem_nodes
...        = exo.get_elem_connectivity(elem_blk_id)

Parameters

elem_blk_id : int element block ID (not INDEX)

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  elem_conn  ordered list of node *INDICES* that
    define the connectivity of each element
    in the block; the list cycles through
    all nodes of the first element, then
    all nodes of the second element, etc.
    (see `exodus.get_id_map` for explanation
    of node *INDEX* versus node *ID*)

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  elem_conn  (same description)

<int>  num_blk_elems    number of elements in the block
<int>  num_elem_nodes   number of nodes per element
def put_elem_connectivity(self, object_id, connectivity): 
2711    def put_elem_connectivity(self, object_id, connectivity):
2712        """
2713        store the nodal connectivity, number of elements, and
2714        number of nodes per element for a single block
2715
2716        >>> exo.put_elem_connectivity(elem_blk_id, elem_conn)
2717
2718        Parameters
2719        ----------
2720        elem_blk_id : int
2721            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2722            <list<int>>  elem_conn    ordered list of node *INDICES* that
2723              define the connectivity of each
2724              element in the block; the list cycles
2725              through all nodes of the first element,
2726              then all nodes of the second element,
2727              etc.
2728              (see `exodus.get_id_map` for explanation
2729              of node *INDEX* versus node *ID*)
2730        """
2731        _d1, numBlkElems, numNodesPerElem, _d2 = self.elem_blk_info(object_id)
2732        assert len(connectivity) == (numBlkElems * numNodesPerElem)
2733        self.__ex_put_elem_conn(object_id, connectivity)

store the nodal connectivity, number of elements, and number of nodes per element for a single block

>>> exo.put_elem_connectivity(elem_blk_id, elem_conn)

Parameters

elem_blk_id : int element block ID (not INDEX) > elem_conn ordered list of node INDICES that define the connectivity of each element in the block; the list cycles through all nodes of the first element, then all nodes of the second element, etc. (see exodus.get_id_map for explanation of node INDEX versus node ID)

def get_elem_attr(self, elem_blk_id): 
2735    def get_elem_attr(self, elem_blk_id):
2736        """
2737        get all attributes for each element in a block
2738
2739        >>> elem_attrs = exo.get_elem_attr(elem_blk_id)
2740
2741        Parameters
2742        ----------
2743        elem_blk_id : int
2744            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2745
2746        Returns
2747        -------
2748            if array_type == 'ctype' : <list<float>> elem_attrs
2749            if array_type == 'numpy' : <np_array<float>> elem_attrs
2750                list of attribute values for all
2751                elements in the block; the list cycles
2752                through all attributes of the first
2753                element, then all attributes of the
2754                second element, etc. Attributes are
2755                ordered by the ordering of the names
2756                returned by exo.get_attribute_names()
2757        """
2758        elem_attrs = self.__ex_get_elem_attr(elem_blk_id)
2759        if self.use_numpy:
2760            elem_attrs = ctype_to_numpy(self, elem_attrs)
2761        return elem_attrs

get all attributes for each element in a block

>>> elem_attrs = exo.get_elem_attr(elem_blk_id)

Parameters

elem_blk_id : int element block ID (not INDEX)

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype' : <list<float>> elem_attrs
if array_type == 'numpy' : <np_array<float>> elem_attrs
    list of attribute values for all
    elements in the block; the list cycles
    through all attributes of the first
    element, then all attributes of the
    second element, etc. Attributes are
    ordered by the ordering of the names
    returned by exo.get_attribute_names()
def get_elem_attr_values(self, elem_blk_id, elem_attr_name): 
2763    def get_elem_attr_values(self, elem_blk_id, elem_attr_name):
2764        """
2765        get an attribute for each element in a block
2766
2767        >>> elem_attrs = exo.get_elem_attr(elem_blk_id)
2768
2769        Parameters
2770        ----------
2771            <int>    elem_blk_id     element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2772            <string> elem_attr_name  element attribute name
2773
2774        Returns
2775        -------
2776            if array_type == 'ctype': <list<float>>  values
2777            if array_type == 'numpy': <np_array<float>>  values
2778                array of values for the requested
2779                attribute.  Array has dimensions of
2780                1 x num_elem, where num_elem is the
2781                number of elements on the element block.
2782        """
2783        # Determine index of requested attribute in attribute list
2784        elem_attr_names = self.get_attribute_names('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id)
2785        a_ndx = elem_attr_names.index(elem_attr_name)
2786
2787        values = self.__ex_get_one_attr('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id, a_ndx + 1)
2788        if self.use_numpy:
2789            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
2790        return values

>>> elem_attrs = exo.get_elem_attr(elem_blk_id)

Parameters

<int>    elem_blk_id     element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
<string> elem_attr_name  element attribute name

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype': <list<float>>  values
if array_type == 'numpy': <np_array<float>>  values
    array of values for the requested
    attribute.  Array has dimensions of
    1 x num_elem, where num_elem is the
    number of elements on the element block.

def put_elem_attr_values(self, elem_blk_id, elem_attr_name, values): 
2842    def put_elem_attr_values(self, elem_blk_id, elem_attr_name, values):
2843        """
2844        store an attribute for each element in a block
2845
2846        >>> exo.put_elem_attr_values(elem_blk_id, elem_attr_name, values)
2847
2848        Parameters
2849        ----------
2850        elem_blk_id : int
2851            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2852        <string>       elem_attr_name element attribute name
2853        <list<float>>  values         list of values for a single attribute
2854                                        on a element block.  List dimensions
2855                                        should be 1 x N_elem, where N_elem is
2856                                        the number of elements on the element
2857                                        block.
2858        """
2859        # Determine index of requested attribute in attribute list
2860        elem_attr_names = self.get_attribute_names('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id)
2861        a_ndx = elem_attr_names.index(elem_attr_name)
2862        self.__ex_put_one_attr('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', elem_blk_id, a_ndx + 1, values)

>>> exo.put_elem_attr_values(elem_blk_id, elem_attr_name, values)

Parameters

elem_blk_id : int element block ID (not INDEX) elem_attr_name element attribute name > values list of values for a single attribute on a element block. List dimensions should be 1 x N_elem, where N_elem is the number of elements on the element block.

def num_elems_in_blk(self, object_id): 
2900    def num_elems_in_blk(self, object_id):
2901        """

2907        ----------
2908        elem_blk_id : int
2909            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2910
2911        Returns
2912        -------
2913            <int>  num_blk_elems
2914        """
2915        vals = self.get_entity_count('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', object_id)
2916        return vals

def get_partial_element_variable_values(self, blockId, name, step, start_index, num_elements): 
2976    def get_partial_element_variable_values(self, blockId, name, step, start_index, num_elements):
2977        """
2978        get list of element variable values for a specified element
2979        block, element variable name, and time step
2980
2981        >>> evar_vals = exo.get_element_variable_values(elem_blk_id,
2982        ...                                            evar_name, time_step)
2983
2984        Parameters
2985        ----------
2986        elem_blk_id : int
2987            element block *ID* (not *INDEX*)
2988        evar_name : string
2989            name of element variable
2990        time_step : int
2991            1-based index of time step
2992        start_index: int
2993            1-based index of element in block to start returning data
2994        num_elements: int
2995            number of elements to return data for.
2996
2997        Returns
2998        -------
2999
3000            if array_type == 'ctype':
3001              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals
3002
3003            if array_type == 'numpy':
3004              <np_array<double>>  evar_vals
3005        """
3006        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_ELEM_BLOCK')
3007        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
3008        values = self.__ex_get_partial_var(step, 'EX_ELEM_BLOCK', var_id, blockId, start_index, num_elements)
3009        if self.use_numpy:
3010            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
3011        return values

get list of element variable values for a specified element block, element variable name, and time step

>>> evar_vals = exo.get_element_variable_values(elem_blk_id,
...                                            evar_name, time_step)

Parameters

elem_blk_id : int element block ID (not INDEX) evar_name : string name of element variable time_step : int 1-based index of time step start_index: int 1-based index of element in block to start returning data num_elements: int number of elements to return data for.

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<ctypes.c_double>>  evar_vals

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<double>>  evar_vals

3021        ...             evar_name, time_step, evar_vals)

3032        -------
3033        status : bool
3034            True = successful execution

def put_element_variable_name(self, name, index): 
3091    def put_element_variable_name(self, name, index):
3092        """
3093        add the name and index of a new element variable to the model;
3094        element variable indexing goes from 1 to
3095        exo.get_element_variable_number()
3096
3097        >>> status = exo.put_element_variable_name(evar_name, evar_index)
3098
3099        Parameters
3100        ----------
3101            <string>  evar_name   name of new element variable
3102            <int>     evar_index  1-based index of new element variable
3103
3104        Returns
3105        -------
3106        status : bool
3107            True = successful execution
3108
3109        Note:
3110        ----
3111        this method is often called within the following sequence:
3112
3113        >>> num_evars = exo.get_element_variable_number()
3114        >>> new_evar_index = num_evars + 1
3115        >>> num_evars += 1
3116        >>> exo.set_element_variable_number(num_evars)
3117        >>> exo.put_element_variable_name("new_evar", new_evar_index)
3118        """
3119        EBvarNames = self.get_variable_names('EX_ELEM_BLOCK')
3120        if name in EBvarNames:
3121            print(f'WARNING: element variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
3122        if index > len(EBvarNames):
3123            print(("index", index, "len", len(EBvarNames)))
3124            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
3125        self.__ex_put_variable_name('EX_ELEM_BLOCK', index, name)
3126        return True

add the name and index of a new element variable to the model; element variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_element_variable_number()

>>> status = exo.put_element_variable_name(evar_name, evar_index)

Parameters

<string>  evar_name   name of new element variable
<int>     evar_index  1-based index of new element variable

Returns

status : bool True = successful execution

Note:

this method is often called within the following sequence:

>>> num_evars = exo.get_element_variable_number()
>>> new_evar_index = num_evars + 1
>>> num_evars += 1
>>> exo.set_element_variable_number(num_evars)
>>> exo.put_element_variable_name("new_evar", new_evar_index)

def get_node_set_ids(self): 
3298    def get_node_set_ids(self):
3299        """
3300        get mapping of exodus node set index to user- or application-
3301        defined node set id; node_set_ids is ordered
3302        by the *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from
3303        1 to exo.num_node_sets(), used by exodus for storage
3304        and input/output of array data stored on the node sets; a
3305        user or application can optionally use a separate node set
3306        *ID* numbering system, so the node_set_ids array points to the
3307        node set *ID* for each node set *INDEX*
3308
3309        >>> node_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')
3310
3311        Returns
3312        -------
3313
3314            if array_type == 'ctype':
3315              <list<int>>  node_set_ids
3316
3317            if array_type == 'numpy':
3318              <np_array<int>>  node_set_ids
3319        """
3320        return self.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')

get mapping of exodus node set index to user- or application- defined node set id; node_set_ids is ordered by the INDEX ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to exo.num_node_sets(), used by exodus for storage and input/output of array data stored on the node sets; a user or application can optionally use a separate node set ID numbering system, so the node_set_ids array points to the node set ID for each node set INDEX

>>> node_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  node_set_ids

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  node_set_ids

def num_nodes_in_node_set(self, object_id):

3401            <int>  num_ns_nodes

get the number of nodes in a node set

>>> num_ns_nodes = exo.num_nodes_in_node_set(node_set_id)

Parameters

<int>  node_set_id  node set *ID* (not *INDEX*)

Returns

<int>  num_ns_nodes
def get_node_set_nodes(self, object_id): 
3408    def get_node_set_nodes(self, object_id):
3409        """
3410        get the list of node *INDICES* in a node set
3411        (see `exodus.get_id_map` for explanation of node *INDEX*
3412        versus node *ID*)
3413
3414        >>> ns_nodes = exo.get_node_set_nodes(node_set_id)
3415
3416        Parameters
3417        ----------
3418            <int>  node_set_id  node set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
3419
3420        Returns
3421        -------
3422
3423            if array_type == 'ctype':
3424              <list<int>>  ns_nodes
3425
3426            if array_type == 'numpy':
3427              <np_array<int>>  ns_nodes
3428        """
3429        node_set_ids = self.get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')
3430        assert object_id in node_set_ids
3431        node_set_nodes = self.__ex_get_node_set(object_id)
3432        node_set_nodes = list(node_set_nodes)
3433        if self.use_numpy:
3434            node_set_nodes = self.np.array(node_set_nodes)
3435        return node_set_nodes

get the list of node INDICES in a node set (see exodus.get_id_map for explanation of node INDEX versus node ID)

>>> ns_nodes = exo.get_node_set_nodes(node_set_id)

Parameters

<int>  node_set_id  node set *ID* (not *INDEX*)

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  ns_nodes

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  ns_nodes

def get_node_set_dist_facts(self, object_id): 
3456    def get_node_set_dist_facts(self, object_id):
3457        """
3458        get the list of distribution factors for nodes in a node set
3459
3460        >>> ns_dist_facts = exo.get_node_set_dist_facts(node_set_id)
3461
3462        Parameters
3463        ----------
3464            <int>        node_set_id  node set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
3465
3466        Returns
3467        -------
3468
3469            if array_type == 'ctype':
3470              <list<float>>  ns_dist_facts  a list of distribution factors,
3471                e.g. nodal 'weights'
3472
3473            if array_type == 'numpy':
3474              <np_array<double>>  ns_dist_facts  a list of distribution
3475                factors, e.g. nodal
3476                'weights'
3477        """
3478        node_set_dfs = self.__ex_get_node_set_dist_fact(object_id)
3479        node_set_dfs = list(node_set_dfs)
3480        if self.use_numpy:
3481            node_set_dfs = self.np.array(node_set_dfs)
3482        return node_set_dfs

def get_node_set_variable_names(self):

3557

3560              <list<string>>  nsvar_names
3561        """
3562        if self.__ex_get_variable_param('EX_NODE_SET').value == 0:
3563            return []
3564        return self.__ex_get_variable_names('EX_NODE_SET')

def put_node_set_variable_name(self, name, index): 
3568    def put_node_set_variable_name(self, name, index):
3569        """
3570        add the name and index of a new node set variable to the model;
3571        node set variable indexing goes from 1 to
3572        exo.get_node_set_variable_number()
3573
3574        >>> status = exo.put_node_set_variable_name(nsvar_name, nsvar_index)
3575
3576        Parameters
3577        ----------
3578            <string>  nsvar_name   name of new node set variable
3579            <int>     nsvar_index  1-based index of new node set variable
3580
3581        Returns
3582        -------
3583        status : bool
3584            True = successful execution
3585
3586        Note:
3587        -----
3588        this method is often called within the following sequence:
3589
3590        >>> num_nsvars = exo.get_node_set_variable_number()
3591        >>> new_nsvar_index = num_nsvars + 1
3592        >>> num_nsvars += 1
3593        >>> exo.set_node_set_variable_number(num_nsvars)
3594        >>> exo.put_node_set_variable_name("new_nsvar", new_nsvar_index)
3595        """
3596        NSvarNames = self.get_variable_names('EX_NODE_SET')
3597        if name in NSvarNames:
3598            print(f'WARNING: Node set variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
3599        if index > len(NSvarNames):
3600            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
3601        self.__ex_put_variable_name('EX_NODE_SET', index, name)
3602        return True

add the name and index of a new node set variable to the model; node set variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_node_set_variable_number()

>>> status = exo.put_node_set_variable_name(nsvar_name, nsvar_index)

Parameters

<string>  nsvar_name   name of new node set variable
<int>     nsvar_index  1-based index of new node set variable

Returns

status : bool True = successful execution

Note:

this method is often called within the following sequence:

>>> num_nsvars = exo.get_node_set_variable_number()
>>> new_nsvar_index = num_nsvars + 1
>>> num_nsvars += 1
>>> exo.set_node_set_variable_number(num_nsvars)
>>> exo.put_node_set_variable_name("new_nsvar", new_nsvar_index)

3610        one variable value per node in the set

3613        ...   exo.get_node_set_variable_values(node_set_id,
3614        ...    nsvar_name, time_step)

3624

3626              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  nsvar_vals

3628            if array_type == 'numpy':
3629              <np_array<double>>  nsvar_vals
3630        """
3631        return self.get_variable_values('EX_NODE_SET', object_id, name, step)

def get_partial_node_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step, start_index, num_nodes): 
3635    def get_partial_node_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step, start_index, num_nodes):
3636        """
3637        get list of node set variable values for a specified node
3638        set, node set variable name, and time step; the list has
3639        one variable value per node in the set
3640
3641        >>> nsvar_vals =
3642        ...   exo.get_node_set_variable_values(node_set_id,
3643        ...    nsvar_name, time_step)
3644
3645        Parameters
3646        ----------
3647            <int>     node_set_id  node set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
3648            <string>  nsvar_name   name of node set variable
3649            <int>     time_step    1-based index of time step
3650            <int>     start_index 1-based index of node to start returning data
3651            <int>     num_nodes   number of nodes to return data for.
3652
3653        Returns
3654        -------
3655
3656            if array_type == 'ctype':
3657              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  nsvar_vals
3658
3659            if array_type == 'numpy':
3660              <np_array<double>>  nsvar_vals
3661        """
3662        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_NODE_SET')
3663        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
3664        values = self.__ex_get_partial_var(step, 'EX_NODE_SET', var_id, object_id, start_index, num_nodes)
3665        if self.use_numpy:
3666            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
3667        return values

get list of node set variable values for a specified node set, node set variable name, and time step; the list has one variable value per node in the set

>>> nsvar_vals =
...   exo.get_node_set_variable_values(node_set_id,
...    nsvar_name, time_step)

Parameters

<int>     node_set_id  node set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
<string>  nsvar_name   name of node set variable
<int>     time_step    1-based index of time step
<int>     start_index 1-based index of node to start returning data
<int>     num_nodes   number of nodes to return data for.

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<ctypes.c_double>>  nsvar_vals

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<double>>  nsvar_vals

def get_all_node_set_params(self): 
3698    def get_all_node_set_params(self):
3699        """
3700        get total number of nodes and distribution factors (e.g. nodal
3701        'weights') combined among all node sets
3702
3703        >>> tot_num_ns_nodes,
3704        ... tot_num_ns_dist_facts = exo.get_all_node_set_params()
3705
3706        Returns
3707        -------
3708            <int>  tot_num_ns_nodes
3709            <int>  tot_num_ns_dist_facts
3710        """
3711        nodeSetIds = self.__ex_get_ids('EX_NODE_SET')
3712        totNumSetNodes, totNumSetDistFacts = 0, 0
3713        for nodeSetId in nodeSetIds:
3714            (numSetNodes, numSetDistFacts) = self.__ex_get_set_param('EX_NODE_SET', nodeSetId)
3715            totNumSetNodes += numSetNodes
3716            totNumSetDistFacts += numSetDistFacts
3717        return totNumSetNodes, totNumSetDistFacts

get total number of nodes and distribution factors (e.g. nodal 'weights') combined among all node sets

>>> tot_num_ns_nodes,
... tot_num_ns_dist_facts = exo.get_all_node_set_params()

Returns

<int>  tot_num_ns_nodes
<int>  tot_num_ns_dist_facts
def get_set_params(self, object_type, object_id): 
3721    def get_set_params(self, object_type, object_id):
3722        """
3723        get number of entities and distribution factors (e.g. nodal
3724        'weights') in the specified set
3725
3726        >>> num_ns_nodes, num_ns_dist_facts =
3727        ...     exo.get_set_params('EX_NODE_SET', node_set_id)
3728
3729        Parameters
3730        ----------
3731        set_id : int
3732            set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
3733
3734        Returns
3735        -------
3736        num_set_entities : int
3737        num_set_dist_facts : int
3738        """
3739        (numSetEntities, numSetDistFacts) = self.__ex_get_set_param(object_type, object_id)
3740        return numSetEntities, numSetDistFacts

...     exo.get_set_params('EX_NODE_SET', node_set_id)

def put_set_params(self, object_type, object_id, numSetEntity, numSetDistFacts=None): 
3744    def put_set_params(self, object_type, object_id, numSetEntity, numSetDistFacts=None):
3745        """
3746        initialize a new set of the specified type
3747
3748        >>> exo.put_set_params('EX_NODE_SET', node_set_id,
3749        ...                 num_ns_nodes, num_ns_dist_facts)
3750
3751        Parameters
3752        ----------
3753        set_id : int
3754            set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
3755        num_set_entity : int
3756            number of nodes/edges/faces/elements to be added to set
3757        num_dist_facts : int, optional
3758            number of distribution factors (e.g. nodal 'weights') --
3759            must be equal to zero or num_set_entity
3760        """
3761        if numSetDistFacts is None:
3762            numSetDistFacts = numSetEntity
3763        assert numSetDistFacts in (0, numSetEntity)
3764        self.__ex_put_set_param(object_type, object_id, numSetEntity, numSetDistFacts)

initialize a new set of the specified type

>>> exo.put_set_params('EX_NODE_SET', node_set_id,
...                 num_ns_nodes, num_ns_dist_facts)

Parameters

set_id : int set ID (not INDEX) num_set_entity : int number of nodes/edges/faces/elements to be added to set num_dist_facts : int, optional number of distribution factors (e.g. nodal 'weights') -- must be equal to zero or num_set_entity

def get_node_set_params(self, object_id): 
3768    def get_node_set_params(self, object_id):
3769        """ See `exodus.put_set_params` """
3770
3771        (numSetNodes, numSetDistFacts) = self.__ex_get_set_param('EX_NODE_SET', object_id)
3772        return numSetNodes, numSetDistFacts

See exodus.put_set_params

def put_node_set_params(self, object_id, numSetNodes, numSetDistFacts=None): 
3776    def put_node_set_params(self, object_id, numSetNodes, numSetDistFacts=None):
3777        """ See `exodus.put_set_params` """
3778        if numSetDistFacts is None:
3779            numSetDistFacts = numSetNodes
3780        assert numSetDistFacts in (0, numSetNodes)
3781        self.__ex_put_set_param('EX_NODE_SET', object_id, numSetNodes, numSetDistFacts)

def get_side_set_ids(self): 
3862    def get_side_set_ids(self):
3863        """
3864        get mapping of exodus side set index to user- or application-
3865        defined side set id; side_set_ids is ordered
3866        by the *INDEX* ordering, a 1-based system going from
3867        1 to exo.num_side_sets(), used by exodus for storage
3868        and input/output of array data stored on the side sets; a
3869        user or application can optionally use a separate side set
3870        *ID* numbering system, so the side_set_ids array points to the
3871        side set *ID* for each side set *INDEX*
3872
3873        >>> side_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_SIDE_SET')
3874
3875        Returns
3876        -------
3877
3878            if array_type == 'ctype':
3879              <list<int>>  side_set_ids
3880
3881            if array_type == 'numpy':
3882              <np_array<int>>  side_set_ids
3883        """
3884        return self.get_ids('EX_SIDE_SET')

get mapping of exodus side set index to user- or application- defined side set id; side_set_ids is ordered by the INDEX ordering, a 1-based system going from 1 to exo.num_side_sets(), used by exodus for storage and input/output of array data stored on the side sets; a user or application can optionally use a separate side set ID numbering system, so the side_set_ids array points to the side set ID for each side set INDEX

>>> side_set_ids = exo.get_ids('EX_SIDE_SET')

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<int>>  side_set_ids

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  side_set_ids

def num_faces_in_side_set(self, object_id): 
3953    def num_faces_in_side_set(self, object_id):
3954        """
3955        get the number of faces in a side set
3956
3957        >>> num_ss_faces = exo.num_faces_in_side_set(side_set_id)
3958
3959        Parameters
3960        ----------
3961            <int>  side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
3962
3963        Returns
3964        -------
3965            <int>  num_ss_faces
3966        """
3967        ssids = self.get_ids('EX_SIDE_SET')
3968        if object_id not in ssids:
3969            print("WARNING: queried side set ID does not exist in database")
3970            return 0
3971        (num_side_in_set, _num_dist_fact_in_set) = self.__ex_get_set_param('EX_SIDE_SET', object_id)
3972        return num_side_in_set

>>> num_ss_faces = exo.num_faces_in_side_set(side_set_id)

def get_all_side_set_params(self): 
3976    def get_all_side_set_params(self):
3977        """
3978        get total number of sides, nodes, and distribution factors
3979        (e.g. nodal 'weights') combined among all side sets
3980
3981        >>> tot_num_ss_sides, tot_num_ss_nodes, tot_num_ss_dist_facts =
3982        ...          exo.get_all_side_set_params()
3983
3984        Returns
3985        -------
3986            <int>  tot_num_ss_sides
3987            <int>  tot_num_ss_nodes
3988            <int>  tot_num_ss_dist_facts
3989
3990        Note:
3991        -----
3992        The number of nodes (and distribution factors) in a side set is
3993        the sum of all face nodes.  A single node can be counted more
3994        than once, i.e. once for each face it belongs to in the side set.
3995        """
3996        ids = self.__ex_get_ids('EX_SIDE_SET')
3997        totNumSetSides, totNumSetDistFacts = 0, 0  # totNumSetDistFacts = totNumSetNodes
3998        for sideSetId in ids:
3999            (numSetSides, numSetDistFacts) = self.__ex_get_set_param('EX_SIDE_SET', sideSetId)
4000            totNumSetSides += numSetSides
4001            totNumSetDistFacts += numSetDistFacts
4002        totNumSetNodes = totNumSetDistFacts
4003        return totNumSetSides, totNumSetNodes, totNumSetDistFacts

get total number of sides, nodes, and distribution factors (e.g. nodal 'weights') combined among all side sets

>>> tot_num_ss_sides, tot_num_ss_nodes, tot_num_ss_dist_facts =
...          exo.get_all_side_set_params()

Returns

<int>  tot_num_ss_sides
<int>  tot_num_ss_nodes
<int>  tot_num_ss_dist_facts

Note:

The number of nodes (and distribution factors) in a side set is the sum of all face nodes. A single node can be counted more than once, i.e. once for each face it belongs to in the side set.

4007    def get_side_set_params(self, object_id):
4008        """
4009        get number of sides and nodal distribution factors (e.g. nodal
4010        'weights') in a side set
4011
4012        >>> num_ss_sides, num_ss_dist_facts = exo.get_side_set_params(side_set_id)
4013
4014        Parameters
4015        ----------
4016            <int>  side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4017
4018        Returns
4019        -------

4021            <int>  num_ss_dist_facts

4023        Note:
4024        -----
4025        The number of nodes (and distribution factors) in a side set is
4026        the sum of all face nodes.  A single node can be counted more
4027        than once, i.e. once for each face it belongs to in the side set.
4028        """
4029        (numSetSides, numSetDistFacts) = self.__ex_get_set_param('EX_SIDE_SET', object_id)
4030        return numSetSides, numSetDistFacts

def put_side_set_params(self, object_id, numSetSides, numSetDistFacts): 
4034    def put_side_set_params(self, object_id, numSetSides, numSetDistFacts):
4035        """
4036        initialize a new side set

4039
4040        Parameters
4041        ----------

4043            <int>  num_ss_sides       number of sides to be added to set

4045              (e.g. nodal 'weights')
4046

4048        -----

4050        the sum of all face nodes.  A single node can be counted more

initialize a new side set

>>> exo.put_side_set_params(side_set_id, num_ss_sides, num_ss_dist_facts)

Parameters

<int>  side_set_id        side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
<int>  num_ss_sides       number of sides to be added to set
<int>  num_ss_dist_facts  number of nodal distribution factors
  (e.g. nodal 'weights')

Note:

The number of nodes (and distribution factors) in a side set is the sum of all face nodes. A single node can be counted more than once, i.e. once for each face it belongs to in the side set.

def get_side_set(self, object_id): 
4057    def get_side_set(self, object_id):
4058        """
4059        get the lists of element and side indices in a side set; the
4060        two lists correspond: together, ss_elems[i] and ss_sides[i]
4061        define the face of an element
4062
4063        >>> ss_elems, ss_sides = exo.get_side_set(side_set_id)
4064
4065        Parameters
4066        ----------
4067            <int>  side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4068
4069        Returns
4070        -------
4071
4072            if array_type == 'ctype':
4073              <list<int>>  ss_elems
4074              <list<int>>  ss_sides
4075
4076            if array_type == 'numpy':
4077              <np_array<int>>  ss_elems
4078              <np_array<int>>  ss_sides
4079        """
4080        (side_set_elem_list, side_set_side_list) = self.__ex_get_side_set(object_id)
4081        if self.use_numpy:
4082            side_set_elem_list = ctype_to_numpy(self, side_set_elem_list)
4083            side_set_side_list = ctype_to_numpy(self, side_set_side_list)
4084        return side_set_elem_list, side_set_side_list

get the lists of element and side indices in a side set; the two lists correspond: together, ss_elems[i] and ss_sides[i] define the face of an element

>>> ss_elems, ss_sides = exo.get_side_set(side_set_id)

Parameters

<int>  side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)

  <list<int>>  ss_sides

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<int>>  ss_elems
  <np_array<int>>  ss_sides

def get_side_set_dist_fact(self, object_id): 
4106    def get_side_set_dist_fact(self, object_id):
4107        """
4108        get the list of distribution factors for nodes in a side set
4109
4110        >>> ss_dist_facts = exo.get_side_set_dist_fact(side_set_id)
4111
4112        Parameters
4113        ----------
4114            <int>        side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4115
4116        Returns
4117        -------
4118
4119            if array_type == 'ctype':
4120              <list<float>>  ss_dist_facts  a list of distribution factors,
4121                e.g. nodal 'weights'
4122
4123            if array_type == 'numpy':
4124              <np_array<double>>  ss_dist_facts  a list of distribution
4125                factors, e.g. nodal
4126                'weights'
4127
4128        Note:
4129        -----
4130        The number of nodes (and distribution factors) in a side set is
4131        the sum of all face nodes.  A single node can be counted more
4132        than once, i.e. once for each face it belongs to in the side set.
4133        """
4134        side_set_dfs = list(self.__ex_get_side_set_dist_fact(object_id))
4135        if self.use_numpy:
4136            side_set_dfs = self.np.array(side_set_dfs)
4137        return side_set_dfs

def get_side_set_node_list(self, object_id): 
4163    def get_side_set_node_list(self, object_id):
4164        """
4165        get two lists:
4166         1. number of nodes for each side in the set
4167         2. concatenation of the nodes for each side in the set
4168
4169        >>> ss_num_nodes_per_side, ss_nodes = exo.get_side_set_node_list(side_set_id)
4170
4171        Parameters
4172        ----------
4173            <int>        side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4174
4175        Returns
4176        -------
4177
4178            if array_type == 'ctype':
4179              <list<int>>  ss_num_side_nodes
4180              <list<int>>  ss_nodes
4181
4182            if array_type == 'numpy':
4183              <np_array<int>>  ss_num_side_nodes
4184              <np_array<int>>  ss_nodes
4185
4186        Note:
4187        -----
4188        The number of nodes (and distribution factors) in a side set is
4189        the sum of all face nodes.  A single node can be counted more
4190        than once, i.e. once for each face it belongs to in the side set.
4191        """
4192        (side_set_node_cnt_list,
4193         side_set_node_list) = self.__ex_get_side_set_node_list(object_id)
4194        if self.use_numpy:
4195            side_set_node_cnt_list = ctype_to_numpy(
4196                self, side_set_node_cnt_list)
4197            side_set_node_list = ctype_to_numpy(self, side_set_node_list)
4198        return side_set_node_cnt_list, side_set_node_list

  2. concatenation of the nodes for each side in the set

4261        """

def put_side_set_variable_name(self, name, index): 
4268    def put_side_set_variable_name(self, name, index):
4269        """
4270        add the name and index of a new side set variable to the model;
4271        side set variable indexing goes from 1 to
4272        exo.get_side_set_variable_number()
4273
4274        >>> status = exo.put_side_set_variable_name(ssvar_name, ssvar_index)
4275
4276        Parameters
4277        ----------
4278            <string>  ssvar_name   name of new side set variable
4279            <int>     ssvar_index  1-based index of new side set variable
4280
4281        Returns
4282        -------
4283        status : bool
4284            True = successful execution
4285
4286        Note:
4287        -----
4288        this method is often called within the following sequence:
4289
4290        >>> num_ssvars = exo.get_side_set_variable_number()
4291        >>> new_ssvar_index = num_ssvars + 1
4292        >>> num_ssvars += 1
4293        >>> exo.set_side_set_variable_number(num_ssvars)
4294        >>> exo.put_side_set_variable_name("new_ssvar", new_ssvar_index)
4295
4296        """
4297        SSvarNames = self.get_variable_names('EX_SIDE_SET')
4298        if name in SSvarNames:
4299            print(f'WARNING: Side set variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
4300        if index > len(SSvarNames):
4301            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
4302        self.__ex_put_variable_name('EX_SIDE_SET', index, name)
4303        return True

add the name and index of a new side set variable to the model; side set variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_side_set_variable_number()

>>> status = exo.put_side_set_variable_name(ssvar_name, ssvar_index)

Parameters

<string>  ssvar_name   name of new side set variable
<int>     ssvar_index  1-based index of new side set variable

Returns

status : bool True = successful execution

Note:

this method is often called within the following sequence:

>>> num_ssvars = exo.get_side_set_variable_number()
>>> new_ssvar_index = num_ssvars + 1
>>> num_ssvars += 1
>>> exo.set_side_set_variable_number(num_ssvars)
>>> exo.put_side_set_variable_name("new_ssvar", new_ssvar_index)

4307    def get_side_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step):
4308        """
4309        get list of side set variable values for a specified side
4310        set, side set variable name, and time step; the list has
4311        one variable value per side in the set
4312

4314        ...    ssvar_name, time_step)
4315
4316        Parameters
4317        ----------
4318            <int>     side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4319            <string>  ssvar_name   name of side set variable
4320            <int>     time_step    1-based index of time step
4321
4322        Returns
4323        -------
4324
4325            if array_type == 'ctype':
4326              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  ssvar_vals
4327
4328            if array_type == 'numpy':
4329              <np_array<double>>  ssvar_vals
4330        """
4331        return self.get_variable_values('EX_SIDE_SET', object_id, name, step)

...    ssvar_name, time_step)

Parameters

def get_partial_side_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step, start_index, num_sides): 
4335    def get_partial_side_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step, start_index, num_sides):
4336        """
4337        get list of side set variable values for a specified side
4338        set, side set variable name, and time step; the list has
4339        one variable value per side in the set
4340
4341        >>> ssvar_vals = exo.get_side_set_variable_values(side_set_id,
4342        ...    ssvar_name, time_step)
4343
4344        Parameters
4345        ----------
4346            <int>     side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4347            <string>  ssvar_name   name of side set variable
4348            <int>     time_step    1-based index of time step
4349            <int>     start_index 1-based index of side to start returning data
4350            <int>     num_nodes   number of sides to return data for.
4351
4352        Returns
4353        -------
4354
4355            if array_type == 'ctype':
4356              <list<ctypes.c_double>>  ssvar_vals
4357
4358            if array_type == 'numpy':
4359              <np_array<double>>  ssvar_vals
4360        """
4361        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_SIDE_SET')
4362        var_id = names.index(name) + 1
4363        values = self.__ex_get_partial_var(step, 'EX_SIDE_SET', var_id, object_id, start_index, num_sides)
4364        if self.use_numpy:
4365            values = ctype_to_numpy(self, values)
4366        return values

get list of side set variable values for a specified side set, side set variable name, and time step; the list has one variable value per side in the set

>>> ssvar_vals = exo.get_side_set_variable_values(side_set_id,
...    ssvar_name, time_step)

Parameters

<int>     side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
<string>  ssvar_name   name of side set variable
<int>     time_step    1-based index of time step
<int>     start_index 1-based index of side to start returning data
<int>     num_nodes   number of sides to return data for.

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<ctypes.c_double>>  ssvar_vals

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<double>>  ssvar_vals
def put_side_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step, values): 
4370    def put_side_set_variable_values(self, object_id, name, step, values):
4371        """
4372        store a list of side set variable values for a specified side
4373        set, side set variable name, and time step; the list has one
4374        variable value per side in the set
4375
4376        >>> status = exo.put_side_set_variable_values(side_set_id,
4377        ...              ssvar_name, time_step, ssvar_vals)
4378
4379        Parameters
4380        ----------
4381            <int>          side_set_id  side set *ID* (not *INDEX*)
4382            <string>       ssvar_name   name of side set variable
4383            <int>          time_step    1-based index of time step
4384            <list<float>>  ssvar_vals
4385
4386        Returns
4387        -------
4388        status : bool
4389            True = successful execution
4390        """
4391        self.put_variable_values('EX_SIDE_SET', object_id, name, step, values)
4392        return True

def get_global_variable_names(self): 
4493    def get_global_variable_names(self):

4496
4497        >>> gvar_names = exo.get_global_variable_names()
4498
4499        Returns
4500        -------
4501              <list<string>>  gvar_names
4502        """
4503        if self.get_variable_number('EX_GLOBAL') == 0:
4504            return []
4505        return self.__ex_get_variable_names('EX_GLOBAL')

def put_global_variable_name(self, name, index): 
4509    def put_global_variable_name(self, name, index):
4510        """
4511        add the name and index of a new global variable to the model;
4512        global variable indexing goes from 1 to
4513        exo.get_global_variable_number()
4514
4515        >>> status = exo.put_global_variable_name(gvar_name, gvar_index)
4516
4517        Parameters
4518        ----------
4519            <string>  gvar_name   name of new global variable
4520            <int>     gvar_index  1-based index of new global variable
4521
4522        Returns
4523        -------
4524        status : bool
4525            True = successful execution
4526
4527        Note:
4528        -----
4529        this method is often called within the following sequence:
4530
4531        >>> num_gvars = exo.get_global_variable_number()
4532        >>> new_gvar_index = num_gvars + 1
4533        >>> num_gvars += 1
4534        >>> exo.set_global_variable_number(num_gvars)
4535        >>> exo.put_global_variable_name("new_gvar", new_gvar_index)
4536        """
4537        GlobVarNames = self.get_variable_names('EX_GLOBAL')
4538        if name in GlobVarNames:
4539            print(f'WARNING: Global variable \"{name}\" already exists.')
4540        if index > len(GlobVarNames):
4541            print(("index", index, "len", len(GlobVarNames)))
4542            raise Exception("ERROR: variable index out of range.")
4543        self.__ex_put_variable_name('EX_GLOBAL', index, name)
4544        return True

add the name and index of a new global variable to the model; global variable indexing goes from 1 to exo.get_global_variable_number()

>>> status = exo.put_global_variable_name(gvar_name, gvar_index)

Parameters

<string>  gvar_name   name of new global variable
<int>     gvar_index  1-based index of new global variable

Returns

status : bool True = successful execution

Note:

this method is often called within the following sequence:

>>> num_gvars = exo.get_global_variable_number()
>>> new_gvar_index = num_gvars + 1
>>> num_gvars += 1
>>> exo.set_global_variable_number(num_gvars)
>>> exo.put_global_variable_name("new_gvar", new_gvar_index)
def get_global_variable_value(self, name, step): 
4548    def get_global_variable_value(self, name, step):
4549        """
4550        get a global variable value for a specified global variable
4551        name and time step
4552
4553        >>> gvar_val = exo.get_global_variable_value(gvar_name, time_step)
4554
4555        Parameters
4556        ----------
4557            <string>  gvar_name  name of global variable
4558            <int>     time_step  1-based index of time step
4559
4560        Returns
4561        -------
4562            <float>  gvar_val
4563        """
4564        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_GLOBAL')
4565        var_id = names.index(name)
4566        num = self.__ex_get_variable_param('EX_GLOBAL')
4567        gvalues = self.__ex_get_var(step, 'EX_GLOBAL', 0, 1, num.value)
4568        return gvalues[var_id]

get a global variable value for a specified global variable name and time step

>>> gvar_val = exo.get_global_variable_value(gvar_name, time_step)

Parameters

<string>  gvar_name  name of global variable
<int>     time_step  1-based index of time step

Returns

<float>  gvar_val
def get_all_global_variable_values(self, step): 
4572    def get_all_global_variable_values(self, step):
4573        """
4574        get all global variable values (one for each global variable
4575        name, and in the order given by exo.get_global_variable_names())
4576        at a specified time step
4577
4578        >>> gvar_vals = exo.get_all_global_variable_values(time_step)
4579
4580        Parameters
4581        ----------
4582            <int>     time_step  1-based index of time step
4583
4584        Returns
4585        -------
4586
4587            if array_type == 'ctype':
4588              <list<float>>  gvar_vals
4589
4590            if array_type == 'numpy':
4591              <np_array<double>>  gvar_vals
4592        """
4593        num = self.__ex_get_variable_param('EX_GLOBAL')
4594        gvalues = self.__ex_get_var(step, 'EX_GLOBAL', 0, 1, num.value)
4595        values = [gvalues[i] for i in range(num.value)]
4596        if self.use_numpy:
4597            values = self.np.array(values)
4598        return values

get all global variable values (one for each global variable name, and in the order given by exo.get_global_variable_names()) at a specified time step

>>> gvar_vals = exo.get_all_global_variable_values(time_step)

Parameters

<int>     time_step  1-based index of time step

Returns

if array_type == 'ctype':
  <list<float>>  gvar_vals

if array_type == 'numpy':
  <np_array<double>>  gvar_vals
def put_global_variable_value(self, name, step, value): 
4602    def put_global_variable_value(self, name, step, value):
4603        """
4604        store a global variable value for a specified global variable
4605        name and time step
4606
4607        >>> status = exo.put_global_variable_value(gvar_name, time_step, gvar_val)
4608
4609        Parameters
4610        ----------
4611            <string>  gvar_name  name of global variable
4612            <int>     time_step  1-based index of time step
4613            <float>   gvar_val
4614
4615        Returns
4616        -------
4617        status : bool
4618            True = successful execution
4619        """
4620        # we must write all values at once, not individually
4621        names = self.get_variable_names('EX_GLOBAL')
4622        # get all values
4623        numVals = self.get_variable_number('EX_GLOBAL')
4624        values = (ctypes.c_double * numVals)()
4625        for i in range(numVals):
4626            values[i] = ctypes.c_double(
4627                self.get_global_variable_value(
4628                    names[i], step))
4629        # adjust one of them
4630        values[names.index(name)] = ctypes.c_double(value)
4631        # write them all
4632        EXODUS_LIB.ex_put_var(self.fileId,
4633                              ctypes.c_int(step),
4634                              ctypes.c_int(get_entity_type('EX_GLOBAL')),
4635                              ctypes.c_int(1),
4636                              ctypes.c_int(0),
4637                              ctypes.c_int(numVals),
4638                              values)
4639        return True

store a global variable value for a specified global variable name and time step

>>> status = exo.put_global_variable_value(gvar_name, time_step, gvar_val)

Parameters

<string>  gvar_name  name of global variable
<int>     time_step  1-based index of time step
<float>   gvar_val

Returns

status : bool True = successful execution

def put_all_global_variable_values(self, step, values): 
4643    def put_all_global_variable_values(self, step, values):
4644        """
4645        store all global variable values (one for each global variable
4646        name, and in the order given by exo.get_global_variable_names())
4647        at a specified time step
4648
4649        >>> status = exo.put_all_global_variable_values(time_step, gvar_vals)
4650
4651        Parameters
4652        ----------
4653            <int>          time_step  1-based index of time step
4654            <list<float>>  gvar_vals
4655
4656        Returns
4657        -------
4658        status : bool
4659            True = successful execution
4660        """
4661        numVals = self.get_variable_number('EX_GLOBAL')
4662        gvalues = (ctypes.c_double * numVals)()
4663        for i in range(numVals):
4664            gvalues[i] = ctypes.c_double(values[i])
4665        EXODUS_LIB.ex_put_var(self.fileId,
4666                              ctypes.c_int(step),
4667                              ctypes.c_int(get_entity_type('EX_GLOBAL')),
4668                              ctypes.c_int(1),
4669                              ctypes.c_int(0),
4670                              ctypes.c_int(numVals),
4671                              gvalues)
4672        return True
